title: R-Markdown - Introduction to Documents and Presentations
description: This will be a beginner-intermediate level workshop on R-Markdown. We will start from the beginning introducing you to markdown in R, how to integrate code with text, what all you can do with it and make a document and a presentation using automated reports together. Hope to see you there! :)

title: Show and Tell your R Code
description:
Have you been working on code you are particularly proud of? Or do you have some code that is driving you crazy?

Bring it along to this online event and share your triumph and/or frustration. Last time we learned about some hidden gems of dplyr, the magic of facet_wrap in ggplot and some super cool mapping using leaflet. Who knows what this session will bring!

This event will be via Zoom. Those who RSVP will receive the meeting link via email.

title: A Random Forests Tutorial with Examples in R [postponed]
description:
Unfortunately, due to unforeseen circumstances, we will have to postpone today's session to a later date. Apologies for any inconvenience this may cause, and we hope to see you all soon.

---------------
Hello RiveRside community ;-)

Come join us for a virtual evening of networking and learning on Tuesday, June 2nd, 5:15 pm (PST). Don't forget to RSVP to get access to the meeting's ID and password.

Whether you are new to R or a data scientist, join us for a Random Forest algorithm tutorial and see how you can apply machine learning in your research.

At the end of the meeting, we will have time to help each other with any R-related questions.

Please have R and RStudio already installed on your computers. Also please install and verify that the package is loaded and working properly by running the first three lines of code in the tutorial here:
https://rladies.github.io/riverside/2020/05/20/packages.html

Big thanks to UCR Library and UCR GradQuant for supporting us, and to our guest speaker Rebecca Paulette Kurtz-Garcia from Statistics Department, UCR!

See you soon!

ps: are you already following us at @RLadiesRiversd twitter?

title: Post-SatRday Chicago R-Ladies Meetup!
description:
R-Ladies Chicago will be hosting a virtual social Meetup following the free virtual SatRday Chicago conference this upcoming Saturday!

Both events are open to all R-Ladies. You do not have to attend SatRday Chicago to attend this Meetup, but we encourage you to join the conference as it is free and several R-Ladies are speaking!

You will receive information on accessing this Meetup virtually when you RSVP to this event.

--------------

Register for FREE for satRday Chicago: https://chicago2020.satrdays.org

SatRDays are community-led, regional conferences to support collaboration, networking and innovation within the R community. Events are organized by and for the local R community - we have sister events in DC, Los Angeles, Paris, Johannesburg, and more! Check out https://chicago2020.satrdays.org for more information about this specific conference, and see https://chicago2019.satrdays.org for details about last year's conference.

This year's satRday Chicago will be raising money for the Greater Chicago Food Depository. You can donate here: https://www.myfooddrive.org/drive.php?satrday-chicago-2020

Please contact us at satrday.chicago@gmail.com with any questions or concerns.

--------------

CODE OF CONDUCT
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

‚Ä¢ The mission of R-Ladies is to achieve proportionate representation by encouraging, inspiring, and empowering people of genders currently underrepresented in the R community.

‚Ä¢ We are emphatically queer and trans-friendly.

title: Investigating COVID-19 with R: data analysis and simulations
description:
In this presentation we discuss different aspects of COVID-19 modeling in R.

The presentation has significant technical elements, but most of the workflows are generalized and presented in ways that are easy to understand and transfer to other fields.

The presentation has three parts: data analysis, simulations, and framework design.

1. Data analysis (15-20 min)

- Data analysis of data from well known repositories.

- Like, New York Times COVID-19 and Apple COVID-19 Mobility data.

- Application of different data summarizations, visualizations, and machine learning algorithms.

- This is the "warm-up" part of the talk and a fair amount of didactic explanations are given.

2. Simulations (25-30 min)

- Epidemiology models overview.

- Basic compartmental models: SIR, SEI2R.

- Advanced single-site models: SEI2HR-Econ.

- Quarantines modeling.

- Limited resources modeling.

- Interactive interfaces.

- Multi-site modeling and simulations.

- Typical workflows.

3. Framework design (10-15 min)

- This is a more code-technical part that discusses the principles behind the main, novel R packages used in the presentation.

*The Speaker:*
Anton Antonov
Accendo Data, LLC
Senior Research Scientist

Anton is an applied mathematician (PhD) with 28+ years of experience in algorithm development, scientific computing, mathematical modeling, operations research, natural language processing, machine learning, data science, and data mining.

In the last twelve years, he focused on developing machine learning algorithms and workflows for different industries (music, movies, points of interests, recruiting, healthcare.) Currently, he is working on operations research and data science applications to manufacturing and healthcare.

Anton is a former kernel developer of Mathematica.

title: **Postponed**  R-Ladies Baltimore -- Leveraging Python in R using reticulate
description:
**Update May 26, 2020**: Hi everyone, we are postponing this event about reticulate to Fall 2020. However, we are currently planning a new event in June 2020. We will post more details in the next few days. Thank you for your patience during this time and we hope each of you and your families are doing well.

Sincerely,
- The R-Ladies Baltimore Org Team

R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is the local Baltimore chapter for the larger R-Ladies global organization (rladies.org) to promote gender diversity in the R community.

We will have an event on Thursday May 28, 2020 from 5:30-7pm at Allovue (https://allovue.com). We will have presentations on how to leverage Python in R using the 'reticulate' R package!

WHO is this for?
- If you are new to R & are short-budgeted on time!
- If you know and love Python, but want to know how to use in R!
- If you just want to see some awesome examples of leveraging Python packages in R!

*If any/all of this is true, this event might be for you!*

Reticulate provides a comprehensive set of tools for interoperability between Python and R. The package includes facilities for:

* Calling Python from R in a variety of ways including R Markdown, sourcing Python scripts, importing Python modules, and using Python interactively within an R session.

* Translation between R and Python objects (for example, between R and Pandas data frames, or between R matrices and NumPy arrays).

* Flexible binding to different versions of Python including virtual environments and Conda environments.

Reticulate embeds a Python session within your R session, enabling seamless, high-performance interoperability. If you are an R developer that uses Python for some of your work or a member of data science team that uses both languages, reticulate can dramatically streamline your workflow!

AGENDA
5:30‚Äì5:45 Meet & Greet | üç™ | Networking
5:45‚Äì5:50 Who we are | Announcements | What's next
5:50‚Äì6:30 Presentation: What are Shiny Apps and how can you build one?
6:30-6:45 Discussion with audience on other questions / resources
6:45‚Äì7:00 More üç™ and Networking

Details on the location:
Allovue (https://allovue.com)
301 W 29th St, Baltimore, MD 21211
(Room 2003, on the second floor at the end of the hall)

Details on parking: Parking is available at R House (https://r.housebaltimore.com) as well as across the street at the police station or in Remington Row‚Äôs Garage (entrance on 28th Street, that is paid parking though).

FAQ:
Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. However, we ask that cis men come as guests of women and gender minorities to our events to promote a sense support and encouragement for women and gender minorities in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies. Please also take the time to review our code of conduct before you attend: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

The term "women and gender minorities" is inclusive of individuals who identify as female (trans and cis), trans-men, non-binary, genderqueer, genderfluid, agender, intersex, and all minority genders).

Important to know:
- If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

Finally, for more information:

title: R Tips and Tricks
description:
Join us virtually for a session all about tips and tricks for improving your R workflow! This session will be perfect for any R users looking for small improvements that can help make their coding practices more efficient. While your co-organizers will help to guide us through the presentation, we hope that other members in our awesome community will be willing to briefly discuss the R tips/tricks that they love and use regularly.

Speaking of which! We are crowd sourcing these handy coding tips and tricks from our community. If you have something that you want to share please fill out the Google survey (link below). All you have to do is fill out the survey and we will make the slide; there is an example tip slide attached for reference in the survey. We would love for each submitter to give a quick explanation about their tip at next week‚Äôs meeting, but we of course are happy to present for those who do not want to or can‚Äôt. If you are unable to attend, but would still like to share that awesome shortcut you use each time you open up R, please submit! We‚Äôll share on your behalf, and your fellow R-ladies will be appreciative!

The meeting Zoom link will become available once you‚Äôve RSVPed.

Looking forward to learning something new with you all!

Best,
Juliette, An, & Sam

Google Survey Link: https://forms.gle/FvwKDJMRvzkL9uVq8

title: Data Analysis with R (Part 3 of 3)
description:
I'm excited about our plan to enhance our programming skills through an online learning experience. As a group, we decided that we will focus on the "Data Analysis with R" course taught by Facebook instructors on the Udacity learning platform. This will ensure that we are all on the same page when we're ready to kick off our R-Ladies Dallas group project.

The course is available for free at the following link: https://www.udacity.com/course/data-analysis-with-r--ud651

Please join the #learning channel in our R-Ladies Dallas Slack community so that we can discuss the course and ask/answer questions you may have about the material. Slack sign-up info provided below.

Agenda
------------------------------
Part 1: Lessons 1 - 4
Part 2: Lessons 5 - 8
Part 3: Lessons 9 - 10 < -------- this meetup event

To prepare for the event, please take time to watch the videos and work through the exercises. They estimate that it may take you up to 4 hours to complete the videos and exercises in Part 3 (Lessons 9 - 10). Actual completion time could be lower depending on how much experience you have with some of the concepts.

You are encouraged to click the link below to keep up with the webinar series and to join the Slack community. Slack is a messaging platform where we will share open job opportunities, free or low-cost online training materials, and R-Ladies group projects that will help you practice your R programming skills and develop a portfolio that could be used to showcase your skills to hiring managers.

Webinar + Slack sign-up: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdJhvSg-YrNYOrmju1yrXvYhFM7xMey1WpDq1NSGIp6x41VaA/viewform

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

About R-Ladies Dallas

R-Ladies Dallas welcomes members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling. Our non-profit, civil society community is designed to develop our members' R skills & knowledge through social, collaborative learning & sharing. Supporting minority identity access to STEM skills & careers, the Free Software Movement, and contributing to the global R community!

A local chapter of R-Ladies Global, R-Ladies Dallas exists to promote gender diversity in the R community worldwide. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R. As a founding principle, there is no cost or charge to participate in any of our R-Ladies communities around the world.

Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

We expect all attendees to abide & be governed by our community code of conduct. Please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct.

title: R Ladies Netherlands Book Club - Advanced R Chapter 5
description:
[ONLINE EVENT]
----------------------
Hi everyone!
The R Ladies chapters of the Netherlands are partnering up! Together, R-Ladies Rotterdam, R-Ladies Den Bosch, R-Ladies Nijmegen, , R-Ladies Utrecht and R-Ladies Amsterdam we are hosting an online book club. Online meetings will take place every two weeks. Our first book is Hadley Wickham's Advanced R (https://adv-r.hadley.nz/).

In our fourth meeting, Margaux Sleckman from R Ladies Amsterdam will present the key points of Chapter 5: "Control Flows". After that, we'll try some exercises together and help each other clear up any doubts and get over any hurdles :)

The link to the event meeting will be provided via **email**, closer to the date. Check the full schedule, previous slides at https://rladiesnl.github.io/book_club/. you may volunteer to sign up to present a chapter at this link as well!

See you soon and stay safe!

ABOUT MARGAUX
----------------------
https://www.linkedin.com/in/margaux-sleckman-88ba02ba/
Margaux is a consultant/data scientist at Metabolic, an Amsterdam's based environmental firm. She is also a core member of R-Ladies Amsterdam. She's a recent Master's graduate from the University of California, Santa Barbara working to advance climate mitigation and adaptation efforts in urban areas. More broadly, She is passionate about using data science for more effective problem-solving vis a vis environmental challenges.

REQUIREMENTS
----------------------
Make sure to read the chapter in advance!

CODE OF CONDUCT
----------------------------
We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct. Anyone who violates this community's Code of Conduct will be refused entry, expelled, and/or any other action deemed appropriate by the Organizer, regardless of event registration, meetup membership or other condition. We are emphatically queer and trans-friendly. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn.

title: May meetup: Databases in R
description:
Need to work with databases, but prefer R to SQL. Priyanka's got us covered. She'll be helping us use R to query data, instead of SQL ;). Please join Priyanka Nagar, and us, for another online meetup!

Materials:
You may follow along if you'd like. Please find the script and datasets at our Github link: https://bit.ly/3gluZmw.

Please download the following packages:
- sqldf
- dplyr
- # install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("sciencificity/reclues")

The `reclues` package above is my package, so really keen to talk with you about how you find it! Criticism welcomed.

Housekeeping:
Our code of conduct remains in place despite the online nature, and any contravention will be dealt with accordingly (https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/).

Link updated. See you all this evening!

title: Writing behavioural experiments in R: jaysire package
description:
R is becoming the programming language of choice for behavioural scientists. It seems like R does everything.... except allow you to write behavioural experiments. Most behavioural scientists end up having to learn Matlab or Inquisit or Javascript to create experiments, as well as R to deal with data.

In this session, our cofounder Dani Navarro will teach us how to use her new `jaysire` package, which allows you to write jspsych experiments in R. Whether you are administering surveys or measuring reaction time or interested in implicit attitudes... `jaysire` might make R your one stop shop.

title: Code-RLadies May Lightning Talk & Workshop - Virtual!
description:
Join us via Zoom: (link will show to any who RSVP).

Our May Lighting Talk: Parallel Computing, with Toryn.

Our May Workshop Focus: dplyr Package, with Toryn.

======

What are Lightning talks? Lightning talks are quick, 5-minute mini-presentations that are showing the art of the possible. They increase awareness and excitement about possibilities. If you want to present a future Lightning Talk, contact us!

What are Workshops? Our workshops help Code-RLadies gather together, network, and learn from each other. Our workshops cover the bulk of the meeting. We believe in being hands-on! Are you interested in leading or participating in a workshop? Contact us!

title: Data Career Panel Seattle UseR x RLadies Vancouver
description:
UseR Seattle and RLadies Vancouver are teaming up to bring you a panel of professionals to discuss career paths, current challenges with working at home and navigating these strange times. Whether you are starting out in your career or a seasoned veteran, the information covered will help you in your career! Bring your questions and notepad!

Here is a sneak peak at some of the questions we will be asking:
-What skills should a new data scientist have if trying to get a job as a data scientist/data engineer/data analyst
-What are some of the most important skills for a data scientist to have on the job?
-Favourite R package or package used most recently?

Panelist Profiles:

Lisa Cao
Lisa works on building open source tools for bioinformaticians after spending a few years doing bench and animal work in biobehavioural research labs. Despite formally is pursuing a Bachelor of Arts she has many achievements in technology such as winning hackathons and landing data science internships. During this event she is interested in helping others with their early career transitions into data science from nontechnical backgrounds.

Ra√Øssa Philibert
Ra√Øssa an environmental data scientist with a background in chemical oceanography. On a day-to-day basis, she contributes to the design, maintenance and management of environmental databases. She also works on analyzing big environmental monitoring datasets for various sectors including government and mining industries. Her main message in this event is that data science includes a variety of fields and has many points of entry.

Arundhati Ghosh
Arundhati presently works on network data products (telecom) with prior experience in Quant Finance and Healthcare analytics. She develops data commodities based on large scale data, related to network usage and user experience. Her primary focus is to derive insights that drive key decisioning. She is interested to help others in starting a career in data science and practical tips for interview preparation.

Ellis Hughes
Ellis Hughes is a Statistical Programmer at Fred Hutch Cancer Research Center where he work on a team that evaluates potential HIV vaccine candidates. After graduating from Washington State University with a degree in Bioengineering, he found a passion for programming in R while working on statistical genetics. Ellis enjoys building packages to support his workflows, learning more about programming, and organizing meetups for the Seattle UseR Group.

More to come!

*********
1. If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

2. Who is this allowed to attend the workshop?
Everyone is welcome to join us at our events and to be a part of our mission to empower gender minorities with the skills and knowledge to code in one of the top programming language in data science, which is R.

3. To fulfill this mission we do ask participants to respect a focus on the encouragement and support for women and non-binary people during our events.

See you there!

Raissa, Lucia, Jasmine, & Lisa

title: Books In Bars - Braiding sweetgrass
description:
Spend Friday night discussing Braiding Sweetgrass (https://www.amazon.com/Braiding-Sweetgrass-Indigenous-Scientific-Knowledge-ebook/dp/B00D0V44LC).

As a botanist, Robin Wall Kimmerer has been trained to ask questions of nature with the tools of science. As a member of the Citizen Potawatomi Nation, she embraces the notion that plants and animals are our oldest teachers. In Braiding Sweetgrass, Kimmerer brings these two lenses of knowledge together to take us on ‚Äúa journey that is every bit as mythic as it is scientific, as sacred as it is historical, as clever as it is wise‚Äù (Elizabeth Gilbert).

Drawing on her life as an indigenous scientist, and as a woman, Kimmerer shows how other living beings‚Äîasters and goldenrod, strawberries and squash, salamanders, algae, and sweetgrass‚Äîoffer us gifts and lessons, even if we've forgotten how to hear their voices. In reflections that range from the creation of Turtle Island to the forces that threaten its flourishing today, she circles toward a central argument: that the awakening of ecological consciousness requires the acknowledgment and celebration of our reciprocal relationship with the rest of the living world. For only when we can hear the languages of other beings will we be capable of understanding the generosity of the earth, and learn to give our own gifts in return.

PS Please contact the organizer if you need support finding the book.

title: [Online event] Mappy Hour with R-Ladies: Spatial Data Analysis in R
description:
Our very own Ayanthi Gunawardana and R-Ladies Chicago board member Angela Li join us this month to talk spatial statistics in R!

This event will be hosted over Zoom, and a link will be sent to all attendees at noon on the day of the event. *Note: Please check your spam or "Promotions" tab (if a Gmail user) for this Meetup announcement email if it does not appear in your inbox. Email nyc@rladies.org prior to the event if you do not receive it.*

Agenda (times approximate):
7-7:05 pm: R-Ladies NYC Announcements
7:05-7:30: "Uncharted Territory: An Introduction to Making Clear and Accurate Maps" by Ayanthi Gunawardana
7:30-7:55: "How to Be a Resilient Geospatial R useR: First Steps, Learning More, and the Spatial R-Ladies Community" by Angela Li
7:55-8:15: Questions and wrap-up

--- Talk Abstracts ---

"Uncharted Territory: An Introduction to Making Clear and Accurate Maps"
Speaker: Ayanthi Gunawardana

Abstract: Over the course of a decade, maps have gone from folded paper booklets inside the glove compartment of a car to having a map of the entire world inside everyone‚Äôs smartphone. As more spatial data becomes available, maps are no longer simple representations of places on Earth; maps now include visualizations of a wide range of newly available spatial datasets. We collect more and more data with location information, but does this mean that this information belongs on a map? I will cover some basic principles of good cartography and what to keep in mind when creating a map.

Bio: Ayanthi is a Data and Research Analyst at the New York City Department of Transportation, where she analyzes car crash data to inform street safety projects and street redesign. Ayanthi has a Masters in City and Regional Planning from Rutgers University, which sparked her interest in maps and data. When she's not looking at maps, you can find Ayanthi at Brazilian Jiu Jitsu class (pre pandemic) or cooking something spicy (all the time).

"How to Be a Resilient Geospatial R useR: First Steps, Learning More, and the Spatial R-Ladies Community"
Speaker: Angela Li

Abstract: Learning to work with geospatial data in R can be challenging, but the right resources and open-source community can help whether you‚Äôre starting out with spatial data or moving your spatial analysis workflow to R. I‚Äôll cover how you can get started with geospatial analysis in R, common questions and challenges I‚Äôve seen, and where you can turn when you get stuck. I‚Äôll draw insights from my experiences working 1-on-1 with researchers, teaching and assisting with spatial R workshops, and fielding questions from the #rspatialchat Twitter hashtag. Finally, I‚Äôll discuss next steps for R-Ladies in the #rspatial community and talk about how we can help each other become better spatial data practitioners together.

Bio: Angela is a researcher and the R Spatial Advocate at the Center for Spatial Data Science at the University of Chicago. She has a background in spatial analysis, econometrics, and public policy. Prior to her current position, she worked at a startup focused on mobility and conducted research on housing and demolition in Detroit. She is currently researching the opioid epidemic in America, working with public health experts to better understand access to treatment. She is passionate about creating opportunities for underrepresented minorities to advance their data science and spatial thinking skills, starting R-Ladies Chicago and the #rspatialchat hashtag on Twitter, among other projects. She is a huge fan of the New York Times crossword.

Angela‚Äôs website is angela-li.github.io. You can also find her on Github at @angela-li and Twitter @CivicAngela.

---

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

description:

El taller consta de cuatro sesiones (6, 13, 20 y 27 de mayo) y tiene por objetivo revisar los principios b√°sicos para que puedas iniciar tu camino analizando datos con R.

¬øQuieres aprender a utilizar R en un ambiente amable e inclusivo? ¬°Te esperamos! No es necesario tener ning√∫n conocimiento previo sobre programaci√≥n.

Esta tercera sesi√≥n estar√° a cargo de Gabriela Sandoval (https://twitter.com/gabysandovalm), estudiante de Doctorado en Estad√≠stica, y se enfocar√° en visualizaci√≥n de datos con el paquete {ggplot2}.

S√≠. Te sugerimos, eso s√≠, revisar los videos de las sesiones anteriores. Est√°n disponibles ac√°: https://github.com/rladieschile/taller-introductorio-mayo

title: [ONLINE] #tidytuesday Work Group
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our May networking event via Zoom, where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio.

This month we will be analyzing the PoKi: Poems by Kids dataset. This will be a great chance to practice text analysis for those of us who are more accustomed to quantitative analysis. https://github.com/whipson/PoKi-Poems-by-Kids

Agenda:
7:00 - 7:15 pm Meet & Greet
7:15 - 8:30 pm #tidytuesday
8:30 - 9:00 pm Discussion

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together! All are welcome, including R-Ladies RTP members and R-Ladies from around the world.

What should I bring?
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a cozy beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: Conversation Analytics with R
description:
Join us for a virtual meetup this May to hear from Jayne Ihaka about conversation analytics!

Overview: What do people say to chatbots and digital assistants? How can we use these data to create a better experience? Jayne will share the lessons she learned using R to extract useful insights from conversations.

Jayne‚Äôs Bio: With a background in biotechnology, Jayne followed an unconventional path into banking and now AI. Jayne works at ANZ New Zealand raising a digital human called Jamie.

This meeting will be hosted on Zoom. The meeting link will be sent out to those attending closer to the meetup date.

If you have any questions or problems, don't hesitate to contact Izzy Johnson (main host) through meet-up!

As with all our meetups, please be aware of and read the Code of Conduct before attending.
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

title: Introduction to RStudio for Data Mapping + Getting Started with R
description:
# Schedule
Tuesday, May 19th, 6:30-8:30pm
6:30 - [Online Networking Activity] Zoom Breakout Rooms
6:55 - Announcements
7:00 - [Career Corner] Getting Started with R
7:20 - 10-Minute Break
7:30 - [R Time] Introduction to RStudio for Data Mapping
8:30 - Meeting Adjourned

# Meeting Location
Out of an abundance of caution regarding COVID-19 and in order to prioritize the health and safety of everyone who attends our events, the May 19th meeting will be held ONLINE using Zoom.

The meeting link will be sent to registered attendees.
Please use the RSVP button to register!

# Presentations
[Career Corner] Getting Started with R
Speaker: Madeline Bauer, PhD

[R Time] Introduction to RStudio for Data Mapping
Speaker: Echelle Burns
Abstract:
Although RStudio has become very popular among scientists, educators, governments, and industry, the nuances associated with geospatial data continue to give novice and intermediate-level RStudio users headaches. This introduction to geospatial data uses location data collected from flatfish and rockfish in southern California to demonstrate how to use RStudio for basic mapping projects. We will discuss the basics of geospatial data, including what shapefiles are and how to read and display them properly in RStudio, as well as how to use RStudio to answer more advanced questions, such as, ‚ÄúWhat kind of environments are these fish exposed to?‚Äù and ‚ÄúAre these fish using areas close to underwater structures, like artificial reefs?‚Äù In general, geospatial data can be used to answer a wider variety of questions and RStudio is particularly useful for displaying trends in these data that may be undetectable by simply looking at values within rows and columns. Let‚Äôs get mapping!

# Live-streaming & Meeting Materials
- All registered attendees will receive a Zoom link to join the meeting. Please see the information above.
- All materials will be sent out and posted on our GitHub (https://github.com/rladies-irvine) after the event.
- The recording of the meeting will be sent out and posted on our YouTube Channel (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIbS1KNK7jbcbQVNt7lF62A) after the event.

title: Virtual Tidy Tuesday - Join and practice your R skills
description:
Do you want to practice your R-skills? Do you want to improve your abilities to clean, analyse and plot data?

Then this event is what you need! We will use the data from Tidy Tuesday as an excuse to work with R. We will virtually meet to work using the same data-set. Each one can choose which analysis to perform or which tools to use (you can already think what you want to practice or learn). We will do this together to have the opportunity to ask others and because coding together is fun!

IMPORTANT:

Given the currens situation the meetup will be hold virtually. We will use Zoom to set the virtual Meetup. You can download it from https://zoom.us/download
You will receive the link to join the meeting viea E-Mail. So check your inbox!

So far the R-Ladies Freiburg have been working really hard in producing super nice plots! The idea of this meeting is to share our knowledge. You can have a look at them on:

https://twitter.com/RLadiesFreiburg

This activity is for everyone, from beginners to experts. You will set your own goal. We will have a coffee (or what ever you prefer) while working together. This way we can have the opportunity to ask others, to share ideas and code!!

It is also a great opportunity to start doing analysis to add to your portfolio on line, so that others know what you can do!

title: Virtual presentations - Discover the package gganimate
description:
"gganimate" is an R package that extends the grammar of graphics as implemented by "ggplot2" to include the description of animation.
You can see some examples here: https://github.com/thomasp85/gganimate

Let's welcome Rhetta Chappell the Data Analystics Web Developer for the Regional Innovation Data Lab (RIDL) at Griffith University. She will share with us a short introduction to the gganimate package and a few tips, tricks and examples from her journey into animated plots in R.
This is a short presentation, so get your questions ready! we will aim to get those answered.

If you want to use the packages from this presentation you can install them on the R console:

# install.packages("devtools)
install.packages("tidyverse")
devtools::install_github("thomasp85/gganimate")

We look forward to seeing you virtually, the zoom link will be shared with those who RSVP.

title: RLadies LA May Virtual Meetup: Writing Functions!
description:
Hello RLadies!

We're back for another virtual meetup! Katie Leap will be giving a workshop about writing functions. We'll discuss when you need to write a function, how they're written, how to find functions that already exist, how to adapt code into functions, and how to use the ideas behind functional programming to make your life easier.

Have a question about functions that you'd like Katie to cover? Post a comment on the event page!

The Zoom link is available once you RSVP. All materials from the tutorial will be available on Github afterward.

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

See you there!
Katie Leap
@katie_leap

PS: We're always looking for presenters! If you're interested, please reach out to Amanda (amanda.k.tilot@gmail.com) or Katie (kleap@ucla.edu).

title: Introduction to Machine Learning in R
description:
Online workshop by Andrew Collier - Exegetic Analytics

R-Ladies Cape Town is excited to host an online Introduction to Machine Learning in R workshop. The workshop will take place over the weekend, with an hour-long session on Saturday and Sunday morning at 11AM. The first session will be an introduction to ML in R, giving us the basics to get us started with a challenge (such as those hosted by Kaggle or Zindi). Participants will be encouraged to take on this exercise at home and work through it on their own or in teams. The second session will be a walk-through of approaches and solutions to the challenge.

Day 1 - Saturday
11:00-12:00

[Take home exercise]

Day 2 - Sunday
11:00-12:00

We recommend that attendees have knowledge of the tidyverse set of tools.

We will send out an email to participants the day before with the relevant links and materials.

The event is capped at 40. If you cannot make it anymore, please do remove your RSVP!

title: PT 1: Workflow Scripts (via Bluejeans)
description: Join us for this hands-on session, via Zoom. Meeting invitations go out the night before the event.

title: (VIRTUAL) Multilevel Modeling w/ MN Public Salaries Data
description:
It‚Äôs easy to get pretty far learning R and basic statistical analysis without really encountering the concept of multilevel modeling. This is unfortunate, because multilevel modeling can be a useful tool when data generating processes are hierarchical in nature--a situation which can be quite common in social, ecological, and political systems.

Alison Link will explore some of the multilevel modeling techniques and philosophies discussed in the book "Statistical Rethinking" by Richard McElreath, and explore how these concepts can be applied to a public salaries dataset on Minnesota state employees. The goal? Learn something new about about multilevel modeling AND generate some interesting findings about Minnesota state employee compensation!

title: Applications of Natural Language Processing (NLP) in Finance using R & Python
description:
Natural Language Processing is a contemporary topic in a variety of different fields. We will go over some applications of NLP in Finance using R and Python. In this talk, we will provide a framework for assessing different machine learning applications generally and specifically on sentiment analysis. We will then go over a couple of case studies of NLP apps for financial applications; their design, architecture, and how R and Python were leveraged in building them. We will conclude with future extensions, further research, and open it up for Q&A.

The Speaker: ---
Moody is a Group Manager of New Product Development at S&P Global within Market Intelligence, he leads a team focusing on applying modelling techniques, such as machine learning and data sciences to distill information value for risk management based signals. Previously, he was Co-Head of Research and Development at Credit Market Analysis (CMA), where he lead the model development and research on Credit Default Swaps pricing and risk management. Prior to CMA, Moody was a Senior Quantitative Analyst at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) Group, where we worked on Over-The-Counter (OTC) Clearing of Interest Rate and Credit Derivatives and the SPAN Margining Algorithm. Prior to that he had several senior roles in analytical & technical consulting, spanning diverse areas from Asset-Liability Management (ALM) to Business Intelligence (BI).

Moody holds a Bachelors of Science in Computer Science from Georgia Institute of Technology, Masters of Science in Operations Research from Columbia University and MBA from the University of Chicago ‚Äì Booth School of Business.

title: A/B Testing in R - Virtual Event
description:
A/B testing is a simple controlled experiment conducted in user experience research as part of marketing research. The randomized experiment consists of variants A and B where a change in one can influence the user experience in a measurable way. It is similar to a two sample hypothesis test. This virtual tutorial demonstrates how to conduct A/B testing in R. The tutorial will cover parts 1-3 of the Advanced A/B Testing Workshop by Elea McDonnell Feit.

Tutorial parts 1- 3:
(https://eleafeit.github.io/ab_test/)
1- Introduction
2- A/B Test Basics
3- When your sample size is big

Speaker:
Elea McDonnell Feit is an Assistant Professor of Marketing at the LeBow College of Business at Drexel University. She develops data analysis methods to inform marketing decisions including designing new products as well as planning advertising campaigns.

-----
Getting there:

This event will be virtual and accessed via Zoom.

title: R-Ladies Columbus Monthly Meetup - Tidymodels!!!
description:
Let's get started with the tidymodels ecosystem together!! We will all learn how to get started with tidymodels, by working together through their 5 "starter" articles https://www.tidymodels.org/start/

The tidymodels framework is a collection of packages for modeling and machine learning using tidyverse principles. The tidymodels team has been hard at work over the past year plus building packages that building and training models easier and more streamlined. We've been super excited about it for a while and the great documentation we are so lucky to have from the tidyverse is now hitting the press - so let's learn about it together!

Be patient with us - we are learning :) Katie will open up RStudio Cloud, and work through tutorials 1-5 linked above. We encourage you all to do the same on your machines and let's just bring up questions and dive deeper as we go! Ezgi, our resident expert will be standing by to jump in when Katie goes off the rails ;)

Script content on RStudio Cloud here

https://rstudio.cloud/project/1276162

title: Introduction to COVID19 data visualization using tidyverse packages in R
description:
Dr. Wall will share with us her work using R‚Äôs tidyverse packages to visualize COVID-19 data. At this event she will show us how to:

-import the data sets from the nytimes and Johns Hopkins github pages (readr)
-tidy them (tidyr)
-visualize the countries or states with the highest number of confirmed cases (ggplot & dplyr)
-apply a sigmoid model to the provinces of China storing them in a nested dataframe
-use broom to look at the parameters for each of those models

Bio: Dr. Jane Wall had extensive software industry experience before earning her PhD at Rice University in computational and applied mathematics. She initiated American University‚Äôs data science program, teaches R and Data Science, is director of data science programs and is co-director of the Masters degree in data science at American University.

title: Data Analysis with R (Part 2 of 3)
description:
I'm excited about our plan to enhance our programming skills through an online learning experience. As a group, we decided that we will focus on the "Data Analysis with R" course taught by Facebook instructors on the Udacity learning platform. This will ensure that we are all on the same page when we're ready to kick off our R-Ladies Dallas group project.

The course is available for free at the following link: https://www.udacity.com/course/data-analysis-with-r--ud651

Please join the #learning channel in our R-Ladies Dallas Slack community so that we can discuss the course and ask/answer questions you may have about the material. Slack sign-up info provided below.

Agenda
------------------------------
Part 1: Lessons 1 - 4
Part 2: Lessons 5 - 8 < -------- this meetup event
Part 3: Lessons 9 - 10

To prepare for the event, please take time to watch the videos and work through the exercises. They estimate that it may take you up to 12 hours to complete the videos and exercises in Part 2 (Lessons 5 - 8). Actual completion time could be lower depending on how much experience you have with some of the concepts.

You are encouraged to click the link below to keep up with the webinar series and to join the Slack community. Slack is a messaging platform where we will share open job opportunities, free or low-cost online training materials, and R-Ladies group projects that will help you practice your R programming skills and develop a portfolio that could be used to showcase your skills to hiring managers.

Webinar + Slack sign-up: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdJhvSg-YrNYOrmju1yrXvYhFM7xMey1WpDq1NSGIp6x41VaA/viewform

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

About R-Ladies Dallas

R-Ladies Dallas welcomes members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling. Our non-profit, civil society community is designed to develop our members' R skills & knowledge through social, collaborative learning & sharing. Supporting minority identity access to STEM skills & careers, the Free Software Movement, and contributing to the global R community!

A local chapter of R-Ladies Global, R-Ladies Dallas exists to promote gender diversity in the R community worldwide. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R. As a founding principle, there is no cost or charge to participate in any of our R-Ladies communities around the world.

Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

We expect all attendees to abide & be governed by our community code of conduct. Please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct.

title: Binovisualfields Package: Development and Publication to CRAN
description:
Hi Everyone! We hope you are all safe and well!!

We have been working to move our coming events online, we hope you will all be able to join us. This month we are excited to welcome Virginia Liu who will be telling us about the development of the Binovisualfields package. This package is for simulation and visualisation of depth-dependent binocular visual fields.

Visual fields are measured monocularly at a single depth in clinical practice, yet real-life activities involve predominantly binocular vision at multiple depths. A simulation and visualisation tool that computes binocular visual fields from monocular ones is useful for researchers and clinicians in the field for many purposes. However, no such tool was available. The talk will provide an overview of the development of the R package and its CRAN submission process.

Virginia is a Postdoc researcher at the Optometry and Vision Sciences Department of the University of Melbourne, a self-taught programmer and UX designer. She has a BMedSci and PhD in psychology.

This event will be held online via zoom. Please connect just before 6pm, the seminar will start promptly at 6. When you connect please turn off your microphone.

We look forward to seeing you all there!

R-Ladies Melbourne

title: R Ladies Netherlands Book Club - Advanced R - Chapter 4 Subsetting
description:
The R Ladies chapters of the Netherlands are partnering up!

Starting in April, we are hosting an online book club. Our first book is Hadley Wickham's Advanced R (https://adv-r.hadley.nz/).

In our third meeting, Martine Jansen from R Ladies Den Bosch will present the key points of Chapter 4: "Subsetting". After that, we'll try an exercise together and help each other clear up any doubts and get over any hurdles :) Make sure to read the chapter in advance!

The link to the event meeting will be provided closer to the date.

Online meetings will take place every two weeks. Check the full schedule, previous slides and sign up to present a chapter at this link https://rladiesnl.github.io/book_club/ !

See you soon and stay safe!

title: Reports to impress your boss! Rmarkdown magic
description:
Because we are not able to meet for a meetup, and the Statistrikk talk is absolutely best to do in person, we are rescheduling this event to August.
Sign up for it in the postponed event: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-oslo/events/270489627/

In stead we will do a meetup on Rmarkdown online!

Rmarkdown is a specialized type of markdown (rich text format) made for R. It provides the opportunity to combine written text with output from R (or even other programming engines) to create integrated documents. It is great for automating report generation, and can make life easier if you find your self needing to do make the same report with slightly different content or input.

Mo (Athanasia Mowinckel) will do a talk with a simple introduction to Rmarkdown, and how it can be used in different settings like reports, presentations, posters etc.

What is network analysis and why is it important?
Network analysis is a technique used to depict relationships between actors. Networks can represent much of our daily lives, like relationships of friends on Weibo, airplane flights between global cities, or messages exchanged across online dating profiles. Network analysis can be used by academics to visualize research data, or by professionals to better understand the flows and interactions in their firm.

Who is the speaker?
Hannah Rose Kirk is a graduate student and Yenching Scholar at Peking University. She graduated from Trinity College, University of Cambridge in 2018 with a double first in Economics (B.A). In China, Hannah worked as a researcher at The Berggruen Institute China Center working on their ‚ÄúTransformation of the Human‚Äù as a 21st century problem. Hannah‚Äôs research concentrates on computational social science, in the application of machine learning techniques to empirical data, but also in the governance of these technologies through her work on digital governance, geo-technical stability, and China‚Äôs AI strategy. Hannah will be starting a PhD in Data Science at the University of Oxford in September.

title: Job hunting and salary negotiation
description:
Event Description:

RLadies are invited to a skill-building workshop to maximize our power as candidates in tech. Together we will:
- walk through strategies for job hunting to boost the volume of offers
- vet tools to assess compensation data
- try out techniques to negotiate for a higher salary
Women who are senior in the industry, mid-career, early-career, and entry-level will have the opportunity to learn, to share, and to practice together in a facilitator-led workshop setting. The goal of this event is to empower RLadies to leverage our competitive strengths and resources in pursuit of great jobs with great compensation.

Facilitator Bio:

Ellen Greer works in Product at Vistaprint Digital and is a former tech recruiter. In the IT field, she has led talent acquisition programs and consulted on job hunts both on the employer‚Äôs side of the table and the candidate‚Äôs. Ellen is a volunteer leader with Femex, a 16-week class that builds community and empowerment with women, trans, and non-binary individuals in DC.

title: R Basic: Graphs (Part I)
description:
These online events will cover the very basics of R and making graphs, which will be ideal for newcomers into the language.

This is a ‚Äúcode walk-through‚Äù; this means we have a code we follow and learn from directly. All the code and data used for this exercise will be provided after the session ends. This also means there is no need for you to run the code or write it down in your Rstudio script as we go along.

As you will learn fast, a lot of the code you will use in R is already written somewhere in the internet. The task for the user is to understand what is happening and learn how to consult the reference guides or how to ‚Äúgoogle‚Äù for answers.

For this first session, users do not need any background information or knowledge. Users with little to some experience may find this first event slow.

Part I - Basics: install and call packages, load dataframes (datasets) and assignments
Making scatterplots: Base and ggplot2

Requirement for Part I:
No special requirements

Part II - Other types of graphs
Making things pretty: ggthemes, Rcolorbewer and patchwork

Requirements for part II:
Being able to create a scatterplot in R on your own

Contact us here if you have any questions or comments before or after the event!

Link to the event: https://meet.jit.si/IntroToR
You can open this link in a browser in your computer. If you use it in your phone you will be required to download an app.

title: Tidy Tuesday - Tips and Tricks
description:
Hi R-Ladies!

We will start meeting virtually! We thought that the best way to try the virtual-meeting for the first time is starting by our already traditional and popular tidy Tuesday evenings.
We will recap what we have been doing and share some R-Studio tip and tricks to analyse data!
We are going to use Zoom for our meeting. So remember to download it before into your computer (https://zoom.us/download).
For security reasons, we will not share the zoom-link on Meetup. We will send an E-mail to all the people that have confirmed attendance. So RSVP and confirm attendance at least half an hour before the start of the event.
We hope to see you there!

title: Learning & Community Building in Data Science: Conference Talks!
description:
R-Ladies organizers Angela and Katherine will each present talks on community building and teaching in the context of data science. Please join us!

These talks are a preview of Angela and Katherine's upcoming presentations at csv,conf,v5. Please join us to discuss these topics and let us know what you are interested in learning more about!

csv,conf,v5 is a community driven data conference on May 13 & 14. It is an event that's not literally about the CSV file format, but rather about what CSV represents to our wider community ideals (data interoperability, hackability, simplicity, etc.). Due to COVID-19, the conference is now 100% virtual and open to all. Find more information about csv,conf here: https://csvconf.com/

After you RSVP, you will be provided the Zoom link to go to in order to attend this event.

--------- Talk Abstracts ---------

Data Communities and Those Who Build Them
Angela Li

In order to support the use of data in various contexts, it is important to have champions who demonstrate the value of tools, shepherd new users, and provide support to those learning to use data. In this talk, I‚Äôll cover my experiences with data community building and share strategies from open source communities such as R-Ladies and The Carpentries, as well as the spatial data science community I support at my research center. I‚Äôll discuss the value of the data community builder and their role within / outside of institutions for encouraging uptake of technical tools. Some of the skills needed for these roles may not be what you think: building relationships, being empathetic toward use cases (and users!), organizing events, teaching effectively, and setting strategy for expanding data networks, among others.

Learner-centered teaching for the non-traditional data science classroom
Katherine Simeon (with Diya Das & Angela Li)

There is considerable variability in how individuals learn computing skills. While many formal courses, both online and in-person, are available to learners, typical methods of learning are acquiring knowledge on-the-job and participating in short-term workshops. While these non-traditional contexts are highly successful, instructors are challenged to capitalize on a limited amount of time and resources, while catering to learners of different backgrounds and experience levels. In this talk, we will discuss how pedagogic research can be applied to computing & programming education in non-traditional settings (e.g., corporate training, 1-day workshops, and one-on-one mentorship). Specifically, we will explore how to modify established learning formats in order to address specific needs of learners. Finally, we will outline best practices to facilitate a collaborative and inclusive learning environment that can motivate both instructors and learners.

--------- Schedule ---------

6:00 - 6:10 -- Announcements & Intros
6:10 - 6:30 -- Angela's Talk on Data Science Communities
6:35 - 6:55 -- Katherine's Talk on Learner-Centered Teaching

---------------------------------

title: From Underdogs to Winners
description:
Hello Fam!
We know this time of uncertainty has been challenging for many, particularly those who are just entering the job market or have recently been laid off due to the current pandemic. We want you to know that we are here for you, no matter what. Allow us a moment to relieve any discouragement you may feel and present you with an exciting opportunity to use this time to make yourself stand out from the crowd when things pick back up!

This is why R-Ladies Miami + Women Techmakers Miami has teamed up with Wonsulting to offer you a webinar on how to make yourself marketable in post COVID world, online and offline!

*Zoom link will be sent to ATTENDEES*

About Wonsulting:
Wonsulting was created with one goal in mind: to turn underdogs into winners. Helping those who come from non-traditional backgrounds/non-target schools to get them into their dream careers.

They have conducted 75+ workshops/events at 40+ universities both domestically in the United States and globally in other countries including Canada and Israel. Visit http://www.wonsulting.com for more information!

Our speakers:

*Alice Wu*: A third year student at UC Riverside studying Business Analytics and Applied Statistics. This summer she will start at Intel Corporation as a Business Analytics Intern. In her free time, she loves to workout, cook, volunteer, and travel.

*Jane Zhao*: Jane Zhao works at Indeed as a Client Success Specialist and graduated last year from UCR. Outside of work, you can find her reading books on kindle and working on passion projects related to personal branding.

*Olaseni Adeniji*: A senior computer science student at UDC who is also the president of the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE). He will begin an internship as a Program Manager at Microsoft .

*Rahul Raghunathan*: A third year Business major at University of California, Riverside, working as a Sales Account Manager for Fresh Prints (a custom apparel company). He will begin as a Summer Analyst for Goldman Sachs. On the side, he works on personal projects related to e-commerce and is currently exploring the digital advertising space as a freelancer. In his free time he loves working out, hanging out with friends, and watching Marvel movies.

*Jason Wendel*: Jason Wendel is a senior, Human Resource Management & Supply Chain Management Major, at Indiana University of Pennsylvania (IUP) with a dynamic passion for professional branding through LinkedIn. Throughout his time at IUP, he has gained valuable leadership experiences such as, being the President of the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM) and being a Co-Founder / HR Manager of the American Philanthropic Organization (a student organization that positively impacts the lives of struggling veterans throughout the western Pennsylvania area).

*Roman Lakhnyuk*: A third year business student at University of Alberta in Canada. Roman specializes in sales and marketing, working at Turnip Home as a sales manager and doing contract work for a local home builder running their digital ads. He also holds the position of Partnerships at Wonsulting.

title: Data Analysis with R (Part 1 of 3)
description:
I'm excited about our plan to enhance our programming skills through an online learning experience. As a group, we decided that we will focus on the "Data Analysis with R" course taught by Facebook instructors on the Udacity learning platform. This will ensure that we are all on the same page when we're ready to kick off our R-Ladies Dallas group project.

The course is available for free at the following link: https://www.udacity.com/course/data-analysis-with-r--ud651

Please join the #learning channel in our R-Ladies Dallas Slack community so that we can discuss the course and ask/answer questions you may have about the material. Slack sign-up info provided below.

Agenda
------------------------------
Part 1: Lessons 1 - 4 < -------- this meetup event
Part 2: Lessons 5 - 8
Part 3: Lessons 9 - 10

To prepare for the event, please take time to watch the videos and work through the exercises. They estimate that it may take you up to 9 hours to complete the videos and exercises in Part 1 (Lessons 1 - 4). Actual completion time could be lower depending on how much experience you have with some of the concepts.

You are encouraged to click the link below to keep up with the webinar series and to join the Slack community. Slack is a messaging platform where we will share open job opportunities, free or low-cost online training materials, and R-Ladies group projects that will help you practice your R programming skills and develop a portfolio that could be used to showcase your skills to hiring managers.

Webinar + Slack sign-up: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdJhvSg-YrNYOrmju1yrXvYhFM7xMey1WpDq1NSGIp6x41VaA/viewform

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

About R-Ladies Dallas

R-Ladies Dallas welcomes members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling. Our non-profit, civil society community is designed to develop our members' R skills & knowledge through social, collaborative learning & sharing. Supporting minority identity access to STEM skills & careers, the Free Software Movement, and contributing to the global R community!

A local chapter of R-Ladies Global, R-Ladies Dallas exists to promote gender diversity in the R community worldwide. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R. As a founding principle, there is no cost or charge to participate in any of our R-Ladies communities around the world.

Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

We expect all attendees to abide & be governed by our community code of conduct. Please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct.

title: [Online event] R-Ladies Panel: All About Blogs
description:
We're so excited to have Angeline, Anisha, Emily, and Sharla talk about their experience with sharing their work through blog posts and twitter! Please email us at nyc@rladies.org with your question(s) for our amazing panelists to address, or submit them below in the comments.

This event will be hosted over Zoom. A link will be sent to all attendees at noon on the day of the event.

--------- Panelist Bios ---------

- Emily Robinson is a senior data scientist at Warby Parker, where she works on a centralized team tackling some of the company‚Äôs biggest projects. She is the author of the book "Build a Career in Data Science" (datascicareer.com), a guide to all the non-technical skills and knowledge you need to get into and succeed in data science, with Jacqueline Nolis (https://jnolis.com/). She regularly gives talks and writes on her blog, hookedondata.org, about A/B testing, programming in R, career advice, and more.

Emily's website is https://hookedondata.org. You can also find her on GitHub @robinsones and Twitter @robinson_es.

- Anisha BharathSingh is currently an SEO Analyst at Omnicom Media Group, with over 2.5 years in Digital Marketing. Last year, she started learning R in order to improve her data skills and learn about data science. In addition to that, she started a blog to showcase the data + R skills that she has been learning along with writing about data-related Meetups and books.

Anisha's blog is https://journeytodatascientist.blog/. You can also find her on GitHub @AnishaB95 and Twitter @thesparemoments.

- Angeline is a data scientist at Protacio Analytics LLC, consulting on projects spanning different disciplines. She is currently growing her data science expertise through the data science bootcamp program at Metis. Her background is in epidemiology and genetics and has experience working with data relating to mental health, breast cancer risk, and environmental risk factors. She spends her free time trying to win at fantasy baseball (with data) and practicing French.

Angeline's website is https://www.angelineprotacio.com. You can also find her on GitHub @angelinepro and Twitter @dataangeline.

- Sharla Gelfand is a freelance R developer focusing on package development and reproducible reporting workflows. She is a long-time R user and co-organizer of the Toronto R-Ladies chapter and frequently shares old and new favourite #rstats functions via the hashtag #TwoFunctionsMostDays on Twitter.

Sharla's blog is https://sharla.party. You can also find her on GitHub @sharlagelfand and Twitter @sharlagelfand.

---------------------------------

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/

title: [ONLINE] - Exploring the 'Highcharts' visual in R
description:
Highcharter is a R wrapper for Highcharts javascript library and its modules. Highcharts is very mature and flexible javascript charting library and it has a great and powerful API.

The Highcharter package in R with it‚Äôs navigable nature, graspable syntax and advanced D3JS visuals is a great addition to the R viz space, currently dominated by the Grammar of graphics ggplot2 package.

It can be used to create the a wide range of charts like bubble charts, column charts, tree maps, time series graphs etc using similar syntax and arguments.

Not only does it support R objects but also employs the loved %>% 'pipe‚Äô operator making it seem incredibly familiar to tidyverse users. This homely syntax combined with stunning visuals makes it go-to tool in R shiny apps and R markdown documents.

This will be a hands-on session and we will be creating basic visuals together in the workshop.

Attendees must have the 'Highcharter' package installed on R-Studio to actively participate in the workshop!
Look forward to e-meeting you all!

La modelaci√≥n y optimizaci√≥n de sistemas de cadena de suministro es compleja y dif√≠cil de modelar de manera anal√≠tica. Los modelos anal√≠ticos generalmente vienen acompa√±ados de supuestos probabil√≠sticos restrictivos que no necesariamente reflejan la realidad en la pr√°ctica. description:

Lightning talks are informal, 5 minute talks on anything R, data science, or tech related. Examples are:

* Working remotely with R and R tools
* Earth Day related talks
* Other projects, workflows, visualizations you've been working on!

Try out your Zoom presentation skills and be a speaker! Please sign up here: https://forms.gle/qqmmGVBLqcerfZ676

For a wonderful reference from a previous speaker, please see Rachael Tatman's deck on How to Prepare & Give A ‚ö°Lightning‚ö° Talk:
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1nod6zgs1DQczpxWg_8opKS7gDmzWMmjMNWIxKzjhEWM/edit#slide=id.p

Many thanks to Ookla for hosting us! You will see the Zoom link once you sign up and we will send out a password the day of the event.

Thank you and see you soon!

title: R-Ladies Santa Barbara Mix & Mingle (Socially Distanced, of Course)
description:
Hi R-Ladies Santa Barbara,

We are excited to invite you to (what we believe is) the first ever Zoom gathering of R-Ladies SB next Wednesday, April 22, from 5:30 - 7:00pm. While these times have been challenging (and weird, and frustrating, with a whole lot of other emotions mixed in), we hope we can offer an opportunity to reconnect with other R-Ladies for a casual virtual hangout.

As the new team of R-Ladies SB co-organizers, we are looking forward to introducing ourselves to those of you we haven't met yet, hearing what you are most interested in seeing in our future meetings, and getting to know each other better through some fun (and guaranteed cheesy) icebreakers.

In the meantime, if you have any thoughts/ideas/suggestions for the types of events you'd love to see happen, please let us know by filling out the following Google Form.

https://forms.gle/Vp7Lr4WPUvDDHGuYA

We are looking forward to hopefully seeing many of you next week!

Cheers,
Sam, An, & Juliette

p.s. The meeting Zoom link will become available when you RSVP!

title: R Shiny for research and teaching
description:
Hello RiveRside community ;-)

Come join us for a virtual evening of networking and learning on Wednesday, April 22nd at 5pm (PST). This will be our first-ever Zoom meeting! Don't forget to RSVP to get access to the meeting's ID and password.

Whether you are new to R or a data scientist, join us to learn the basics of R Shiny to see how you can build beautiful interactive graphs straight from R!

At the end of the meeting, we will have time to help each other with Shiny or any R-related questions. Please have R and RStudio already installed on your computers. Also please install Shiny and verify that the package is loaded and working properly by running the first three lines of code in the tutorial here:

https://shiny.rstudio.com/tutorial/written-tutorial/lesson1/

Big thanks to UCR Library and UCR GradQuant for supporting us, and to our guest speaker Ana Gomez (@anacrgomez) from UCLA!

See you soon!

ps: are you already following us at @RLadiesRiversd twitter?

title: [ONLINE] #tidytuesday Work Group
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our April networking event via Zoom, where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio.

Agenda:
7:00 - 7:15 pm Meet & Greet
7:15 - 8:30 pm #tidytuesday
8:30 - 9:00 pm Discussion

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

This month we will be analyzing the Beer Production dataset: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2020/2020-03-31/readme.md

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together!

What should I bring?
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a cozy beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: R Ladies Netherlands Book Club - Advanced R Chapter 3
description:
The R Ladies chapters of the Netherlands are partnering up!

Starting in April, we started hosting an online book club. Our first book is Hadley Wickham's Advanced R (https://adv-r.hadley.nz/).

In our second meeting, Paloma Rojas-Saunero from R Ladies Rotterdam will present the key points of Chapter 3: "Vectors". After that, we'll go through the exercises together and help each other clear up any doubts and get over any hurdles :) Make sure to read the chapter in advance!

The link to the event meeting will be provided closer to the date.

Online meetings will take place every two weeks. Check the full schedule, previous slides and sign up to present a chapter at this link!

https://rladiesnl.github.io/book_club/

See you soon and stay safe!

description:
Practice your data wrangling and visualization R skills with other members of R-Ladies! Tidy Tuesdays are designed by the R for Data Science Online Learning Community to help R users learn in a fun and real-world context.

Read more about Tidy Tuesdays and get the data here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday

We will be converting our regular Tidy Tuesdays to an online format. Join us on Zoom at: https://ufl.zoom.us/j/690685801

But we'd love to see your faces, so rather not :) Don't worry about pets and family members in frame, we'd love to see them too.

These events will supplement, not replace, our monthly meetings.

title: Shutup & Code (virtual meeting)
description:
=====================================================
Topic: RLEL: ShutUp&Code
Time: Mar 23, 2020 06:00 PM EST

Log into Slack: https://rladies-eastlansing.slack.com
(Channels: #howto-r & #2020-shutupncode)
Join Zoom Meeting | On Slack, visible once you RSVP.
=====================================================

###############
WHO is this for?
###############
What is this??? Stack overflow -- LIVE! Bring your own R-coding project to work on. We'll have a few R-Users floating around (via Zoom+Slack) to take questions and give advice as you troubleshoot your R code.

#####
PLAN
#####
Before the meetup:
- Post your R questions in the Slack channels #howto-R & #2020-shutupncode (https://rladies-eastlansing.slack.com)

During the meetup:
- We will answer the Qs via Slack
- Discuss widely applicable Qs via Zoom for everyone's benefit
- Moderators can demonstrate specific problem areas via screen-sharing
- Participants can stop and share progress/Qs every 20-30min

###########
MATERIALS
###########
TO BENEFIT THE MOST FROM THIS EVENT
1. Bring your laptop w/ pre-installed R & RStudio
2. Come with a well-defined, hour-long task
3. Join R-Ladies East Lansing Slack (https://rladies-eastlansing.slack.com) so that you can ask questions in advance, during and after the meeting.

GITHUB
Repo for this meetup w/ setup instructions, slides, and other useful preparatory material: https://github.com/rladies-eastlansing/2020-git

SLACK
Slack channels + Zoom for Q&A; live interaction
https://rladies-eastlansing.slack.com | #howto-r & #2020-shutupncode | Free signup to Slack possible with msu.edu email ID.

ZOOM
Link below

SETUP INSTRUCTIONS (** Before the meetup)
*This is a hands-on co-work/Q&A session. Please join via Zoom + Slack with your laptops.
*Install or update R & RStudio.
*Create a GitHub account (if you don't already have one) & Git
*(Optional) Install GitHub Desktop -- the Git GUI version

Having trouble with installation & set-up? Ping us on Slack (https://rladies-eastlansing.slack.com) in the #howto-r channel.

USEFUL RESOURCES
1. Past workshop material: https://github.com/rladies-eastlansing
2. R for Data Science by H Wickham & G Grolemund (https://r4ds.had.co.nz/)
3. Hands-On Programming with R by G Grolemund (https://rstudio-education.github.io/hopr/)

** Questions? Find us on slack: rladies-eastlansing.slack.com OR
** Email us: eastlansing@rladies.org

title: Introduction to data management in R - part 2
description:
Hi R-Ladies!

We are going to be holding our second R workshop on the 18th of April. For this workshop, Amanda Neves is going to continue the introduction to working with databases, exploring data frames, and querying data in R. This workshop is intended for beginners, but everyone is welcome!
Amanda is biologist and a programmer working with big data, image processing and database management at the University of Calgary, and a co-organiser of the R-Ladies Calgary chapter.

Location: Room 3-10 B meeting room at the Central Library

Please bring your laptop with R and Rstudio installed.

Hope to see you soon!

******************************************************************************
R-Ladies welcomes members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling. Our community is designed to develop our members' R skills & knowledge through social, collaborative learning & sharing. Supporting minority identity access to STEM skills & careers, the Free Software Movement, and contributing to the global R community!
This is a local chapter of R-Ladies Global, an organisation that promotes gender diversity in the R community worldwide. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R. As a founding principle, there is no cost or charge to participate in any of our R-Ladies communities around the world.
We are part of Global R-Ladies group. You can access our presentations, R scripts, and Projects on our Github account and follow us on twitter to stay up to date about R-Ladies news!
Website: https://www.rladies.org
Twitter: @RLadiesGlobal ( https://twitter.com/RLadiesGlobal )
Github: https://github.com/rladies
******************************************************************************
