title: [ONLINE]- Blogdown: Creating blogs and websites with R Markdown
description:
[ONLINE EVENT]
----------------------
Hi, everybody!
We hope that you and your family are doing well. Though times are currently challenging for many of us- we'd like to still give you the opportunity to meet and continue to learn together. Therefore we are excited for to bring you an online workshop with Aurore!

----------------------

Have you ever been curious to create a website in the R environment that is fast, easy, free and beautiful? R Markdown and Hugo magic combined makes it possible. This workshop will teach you how to use the Blogdown package to create and deploy your first static website and host it for free on the dedicated domain of the R community.

We'll cover the steps from your first blogpost up to its deployment in this workshop such that you are all set to start sharing youR passion with the rest of the world.

PROGRAMME
----------------------
18.30 - 18.45 Virtual Welcome
18.45- 19.00 Intro to R-Ladies and a little announcement
19.00- 19.45 Part A of the workshop- creating your first blog post
19.45- 19.55 Break
19.55- 20.35 Part B of the workshop- deploying the website online
20.35- 20.45 Closing

ABOUT AURORE
----------------------
https://www.linkedin.com/in/aurorepaligot/
Aurore holds a Ph.D. in linguistics from the University of Namur (Belgium) and a specialization in advanced analytics and machine learning from Ubiqum Code Academy (Amsterdam). She has more than 8 years of experience working with quantitative and experimental research methods and is currently a collaborator at Tapp, a smart-city cooperative that helps citizens and authorities building more resilient urban environments. As a linguist turned data specialist, she cares about delivering meaningful insights and human-centric visualizations.

REQUIREMENTS
----------------------
Your laptop, a github account and the downloaded package blockdown.

CODE OF CONDUCT
----------------------------
We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct. Anyone who violates this community's Code of Conduct will be refused entry, expelled, and/or any other action deemed appropriate by the Organizer, regardless of event registration, meetup membership or other condition. We are emphatically queer and trans-friendly. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn.

title: Introduction to the Tidyverse - VIRTUAL
description:
*********** UPDATE 04/14/2020 ***********
This event will be virtual. A link to register for a zoom webinar is visible to meetup event attendees where location information is usually displayed. You can register ahead of time. Please get in touch if you are experiencing technical difficulties or if you have any questions.
Link to slides: bit.ly/rlp_slides
Link to RStudio Cloud project: bit.ly/rlp_rscloud
*********************************************

The tidyverse is a collection of R packages that share an underlying, opinionated approach to data structure and analysis. The workshop will cover the basic steps of a data science workflow, importing, wrangling, and visualizing data, using the core tidyverse packages. Familiarity with R and Rmarkdown will be useful, but not required. Complete novices are encouraged to attend! We'll be using RStudio Cloud for this workshop, so if you don't have an account, please sign up for a free one ahead of time at https://login.rstudio.cloud/register.

About our speaker:

Kelsey Keith is a bioinformatics scientist at the Coriell Institute for Medical Research across the river in Camden, New Jersey. Her work focuses on research into the regulation of DNA, where she spends a lot of time wishing all R packages integrated together as smoothly as the tidyverse.

Agenda:

6.00 to 6.20pm: Pizza and networking
6.20 to 6.30pm: Welcome
6.30 to 8.00pm: Introduction to the Tidyverse

Code of conduct:

https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/

About our sponsors:

The Coriell Institute for Medical Research was founded in 1953 by virologist Dr. Lewis L. Coriell. Dr. Coriell pioneered research in aseptic cell culture and cryopreservation of cell lines, eventually leading the Coriell Institute to become one of the first biobanks. Today, Coriell's mission is to advance scientific discovery by preserving and generating world-class biomaterials, while also conducting groundbreaking basic research in biobanking, personalized medicine, stem cell biology, and epigenetics.

The University of Pennsylvania‚Äôs MindCORE (Mind Center for Outreach, Research, and Education) is Penn‚Äôs hub for the integrative study of the mind and seeks to unite researchers, programs, and initiatives involving human intelligence and behavior across the University of Pennsylvania and bring the science of brains and behavior to our community.

title: April R-Ladies Community Meetup
description:
Join us for our April R-Ladies Community Meetup, where we‚Äôll get to know one another and learn new ways to grow our skills as R users and data scientists/analysts.

We will follow community guidance against in-person gatherings and have this event online using videoconferencing software.

If you'd like to attend, please click the link below and fill out the form. You will receive an invitation to the videoconferencing session along with an invitation to join the Slack community. Slack is a messaging platform where we will share open job opportunities, free or low-cost online training materials, and R-Ladies group projects that will help you practice your R programming skills and develop a portfolio that could be used to showcase your skills to hiring managers.

Webinar sign-up: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdJhvSg-YrNYOrmju1yrXvYhFM7xMey1WpDq1NSGIp6x41VaA/viewform

Here's a tentative agenda:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
* We will spend some time socializing and reacquainting ourselves with one another.

* Review of resources shared in the R-Ladies Dallas Slack community
- job opportunities
- online training opportunities

* We will discuss ideas for R-Ladies coding projects

Feel free to reach out to Sydeaka at at dallas@rladies.org if you have any questions!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

About R-Ladies Dallas

R-Ladies Dallas welcomes members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling. Our non-profit, civil society community is designed to develop our members' R skills & knowledge through social, collaborative learning & sharing. Supporting minority identity access to STEM skills & careers, the Free Software Movement, and contributing to the global R community!

A local chapter of R-Ladies Global, R-Ladies Dallas exists to promote gender diversity in the R community worldwide. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R. As a founding principle, there is no cost or charge to participate in any of our R-Ladies communities around the world.

Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

We expect all attendees to abide & be governed by our community code of conduct. Please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct.

title: R-Ladies Columbus Monthly Meetup
description:
Sentiment Analysis!
___________________________________________________________________________________
The Objective is to create a neural network that can predict if a given movie review is positive or negative. This type of computation is also called Sentiment Analysis.

I will be working with ‚ÄúIMDB data-set‚Äù, a set of 50,000 reviews from the Internet Movie Database. They are split into 25,000 reviews for training and 25,000 reviews for testing, each set consisting in 50% negative and 50% positive reviews.

I will use Keras library to build neural network and walk you through building and training model, model tuning with different hyper-parameter (Optimizer, Loss Function, No. of layers, epoch, batch_size ). I will try and improve the accuracy of model by experimenting with different hyper-parameters.

This will be an online meeting. Instructions to join the meeting are given below:

title: #ShutUpandCode
description:
Learning something new on your own is hard! So lets meet up and learn new R things together.

This month we are getting together at UNSW to meet up, shut up (talking is allowed if you are seeking/getting help), and code.

Modelled on the academic writing #ShutUpAndWrite movement (https://thesiswhisperer.com/shut-up-and-write/), the idea is make learning social.

There are only 10 places available at each session, so ONLY RSVP if you are SURE you will come. Please do not take a place from another RLady, and then not turn up.

description:

title: Tidy Tuesday: Practicing Data Science in R
description:

But we'd love to see your faces, so rather not :) Don't worry about pets and family members in frame, we'd love to see them too.

These events will supplement, not replace, our monthly meetings.

title: POSTPONED: Panel session and meetup pre-SatRday
description:
POSTPONED TO AUTUMN 2020:

R-Ladies Newcastle are pleased to announce we will be hosting a panel session with Julia Silge (https://juliasilge.com/about/), a data scientist and software engineer at R Studio, and Mine √áetinkaya-Rundel (http://www2.stat.duke.edu/~mc301/) a Senior Lecturer in the School of Mathematics at University of Edinburgh and Data Scientist and Professional Educator at RStudio.

The event will be an opportunity for R-Ladies to meet up prior to the SatRdays event taking place the next day, so if you‚Äôre in Newcastle the night before please come along. If you‚Äôre worried about attending SatRdays alone, then this will be a great chance to meet a few friendly faces who you‚Äôll recognise the next day. Alternatively, if you‚Äôd been on the fence of making the journey to Newcastle hopefully this will act as an extra enticement!

We're so excited for SatRdays and hope to see as many R-Ladies members as possible. Tickets can be purchased from: https://newcastle2020.satrdays.org/

About the session:
6:00-7:00pm Panel session (approx.)
7:00-8pm Networking

We need your questions!

The panel session will be a chance to ask Julia and Mine about their career history as R-Ladies and the different focuses their careers have had. Both have had rich and varied careers, so this is a great chance to hear about their experiences. We‚Äôll be taking some questions on the day, but for the best chance of having your questions answered please submit them in the comments below or message one of us organisers.

Example questions:
What was it like moving away from academia? And what advice would you give to others thinking about making the transition
What do you think is the most valuable skill you use in your roles as data scientists?
What is your favourite trick in R? E.g. nifty shortcuts, handy functions
What do you look for when joining a new team?
Do you have any advice on making sure we‚Äôre bringing R-Ladies principles in to our jobs?

We anticipate this event will be well attended so book your place asap. As usual, this event is open to those who identify as a marginalised gender.

Acknowledgements

Thank you to the School of Computing for providing the venue and to Sage for providing pizza.

title: Create a personal website with Blogdown
description:
YOU NEED TO REGISTER.
By noon on Friday 3rd, you will receive a link for the online meeting.

A personal website is an incomparable platform for building your online profile and showcasing your amazing work (research or other interesting stuff). Blogdown is a popular R package developed for producing a static website from R Markdown documents. Even if you are currently using GitHub pages for your personal website, you might be interested in this talk after reading this post by Yihui (https://yihui.org/en/2017/06/netlify-instead-of-github-pages/).
In this talk, we‚Äôll introduce some tips and tricks for building a personal website with Blogdown based on our own experience. This talk is expected to be a hands-on workshop (something fun and meaningful to do during quarantine). Participants would have a chance to build their own ‚Äúbaby‚Äù website and deploy the website online with Netlify!

Preparation: It would be helpful if you register a Netlify account and master some basics about GitHub and Markdown in advance. You can be even more prepared and start to work on your own website now by following this tutorial written by Annie (https://annielyu.com/2020/01/12/blogdown-website/). That‚Äôs how Anabelle created her own website (www.anabellelaurent.com)!

title: Understand word  embeddings using  tidy data principles with Julia Silge
description:
For our April meetup we're so very lucky to have Julia Silge join us! Julia is a data scientist and software engineer at RStudio where she works on open-source modeling tools. She is also the co-author of Tidy Text Mining with R (tidytextmining.com). Julia is keynoting at satRdays Newcastle on April 4, and passing through Edinburgh on her way there. We recommend checking out newcastle2020.satrdays.org for a great, nearby R event as well!

**Understand word embeddings using tidy data principles**

Modern NLP frameworks often depend on word embeddings, a way of statistically modeling language where words or phrases are mapped to vectors of real numbers. In this talk, we‚Äôll work to understand word embeddings by investigating how we can generate them using count-based statistics and dimensionality reduction, then learn how to make use of pre-trained embeddings based on enormous datasets. Finally, we‚Äôll explore the ethical issues involved in using word embeddings and how they can amplify systemic and historical bias.

--

Q: Are men welcome to attend this event?
A: Our primary mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. ***As such, we strongly encourage that all men who attend this event have a female or non-binary sponsor. Please contact mine@rladies.org if you have questions.***

Additionally, please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

venues.name: The Bayes Centre, The University of Edinburgh

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
description:
This is a beginner-friendly session. We'll be working through Chapter 7 of the R for Data Science book, which deals with exploratory data analysis. This is available freely online at http://r4ds.had.co.nz . There will be a short presentation and then we'll work through some exercises together.

Afterwards, there is the opportunity to try this out on our own data. So please, if you can, bring along some of your own data. You could be working on this data at the moment, or it could be something you have used in the past. If you don't have any data, this would be a good learning opportunity to try and find some open-source data from the internet.

This will be an interactive session so please bring your laptop. Ideally, this should have R and RStudio installed. If you have trouble downloading these, you can use https://rstudio.cloud/. You will also need the tidyverse R package. You should install this before coming along to the session. You can do this by running install.packages("tidyverse") in R.

We will be in Lancaster University Library - Room C135. The session will run from 6pm - 8pm with a short break in the middle. Snacks will be provided.

title: March R-Ladies Meetup - Online
description:
Join us for our March R-Ladies Community Meetup, where we‚Äôll get to know one another and learn new ways to grow our skills as R users and data scientists/analysts.

We will follow community guidance against in-person gatherings and have this event online via Zoom.

If you'd like to attend, please fill out this form. You will receive an invitation to the Google Hangouts session.

Here's a tentative agenda:
* We will spend some time socializing and reacquainting ourselves with one another.

* We will discuss some of the issues you might be facing in this new, quickly changing landscape.

* If there is interest, we can discuss the R-Ladies coding challenge

Feel free to reach out to Sydeaka at at dallas@rladies.org if you have any questions!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

About R-Ladies Dallas

R-Ladies Dallas welcomes members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling. Our non-profit, civil society community is designed to develop our members' R skills & knowledge through social, collaborative learning & sharing. Supporting minority identity access to STEM skills & careers, the Free Software Movement, and contributing to the global R community!

A local chapter of R-Ladies Global, R-Ladies Dallas exists to promote gender diversity in the R community worldwide. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R. As a founding principle, there is no cost or charge to participate in any of our R-Ladies communities around the world.

Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

We expect all attendees to abide & be governed by our community code of conduct. Please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct.

title: RLadies LA RMarkdown Virtual Meetup!
description:
Hello RLadies!

Due to the coronavirus situation in LA County, RLadies LA and our other local R users groups are moving our usual meetups online for the next few months. Our first virtual meetup will be Saturday, March 28, at 10am. Amanda Tilot will give a tutorial on using RMarkdown for data analysis and reporting.

"Better data communication & organization with RMarkdown"

What do a static PDF, an interactive HTML document, a personal website, and a slide deck all have in common? You can build them in R with RMarkdown! In this tutorial, we'll work through some common scenarios where RMarkdown can help improve your data communication and organization.

* Shifting from R script files + lots of #comments to RMarkdown notebooks
* Turning your R code into HTML, PDFs, and Word docs with knitr
* Enhancing your RMarkdown files with text formatting and presentation options
* Doing more with code chunks: SQL queries & background jobs

**Schedule**
10:00a - 10:15a Open Zoom, come say hi!
10:15a - 11:00 RMarkdown tutorial
11:00 - 11:15 Extra Q&A, planning future sessions

Have a question about using RMarkdown that you'd like Amanda to cover? Post a comment on the event page!

We'll send out a Zoom link to all attendees closer to the 28th, and include instructions for joining the meetup. All materials from the tutorial will be available on Github afterward.

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

See you there!
Amanda Tilot
@aktilot

PS: We're always looking for presenters! If you're interested, please reach out to Amanda (amanda.k.tilot@gmail.com) or Katie (kleap@ucla.edu).

title: CANCELED EVENT: flexdashboard: Easy interactive dashboards for R
description:
HEY EVERYONE,

THIS EVENT HAS BEEN CANCELLED DUE TO THE CURRENT RECOMMENDED PRECAUTIONS TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF COVID-19.
WE'LL UPDATE YOU AGAIN IN APRIL. HOPEFULLY WE'LL BE BACK TO HOSTING OUR REGULAR MONTHLY MEETUPS BY THEN.

THANKS.

Join us on March 25th to learn more about using flexdashboard in R.

It's an awesome easy way to transform your R markdown documents into great looking interactive dashboards you can share with the world!

Here are some details on this new package (from RStudio):

- Use R Markdown to publish a group of related data visualizations as a dashboard.
- Support for a wide variety of components including htmlwidgets; base, lattice, and grid graphics; tabular data; gauges and value boxes; and text annotations.
- Flexible and easy to specify row and column-based layouts. Components are intelligently re-sized to fill the browser and adapted for display on mobile devices.
- Storyboard layouts for presenting sequences of visualizations and related commentary.
- Optionally use Shiny to drive visualizations dynamically.

We're meeting at 6:30pm at Hera Hub Mission Valley.

We hope to see you all there!

Your R-Ladies SD organizers

title: pRedicaments in R: An R-Ladies Remote Rendezvous
description:
Join R-Ladies Seattle for our first remote meeting on debugging and getting help! Inspired by Jenny Bryan's keynote at rstudio::conf (link below), we will take a deeper dive into how to resolve error messages in R.

We have 2 wonderful speakers who will be presenting.

_Christine Stawitz_
* I'll discuss my process for sifting through the (often less-than-helpful) documentation that comes with R packages, including function reference, vignettes, and GitHub issue forums.
* I'm a contractor at ECS Federal in support of NOAA Fisheries' Office of Science and Technology. I work on improving coding, documentation, and sharing practices for the software NOAA and academic fisheries scientists use to manage marine resources.

_Katie Jolly_
* I'll talk about using the {reprex} package for creating reproducible examples. This package makes it easier to write clear, concise, and readable code questions that will get a more helpful response in return.
* I am a data analyst at Ookla. I am interested in spatial data, information design, and civic data projects.

Details:
* We will send out conference call information to attendees who have RSVP'd "Yes" to this event. The call will be taking place over zoom.
* Thank you to Ookla for helping us get set up with zoom!

Link to Jenny Bryan's talk in case you'd like to view it before our meeting (not required!):
https://resources.rstudio.com/rstudio-conf-2020/object-of-type-closure-is-not-subsettable-jenny-bryan

title: [ONLINE] #tidytuesday Work Group
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! Work individually or with the group and end the evening by sharing your work.

We'll explore a new interactive web tool that was recently developed to aid COVID-19 response in Chapel Hill, NC (https://github.com/code-for-chapel-hill/COVID-Support-For-CH). The Code for Chapel Hill group (via Dr. Kate Hanson) has asked us to provide feedback and suggestions for the tool, which was built using the Shiny package in R. We'll also talk to Dr. Hanson about additional volunteer opportunities for data scientists to help local governments in these pressing times.

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:15 pm Meet & Greet
6:15 - 7:30 pm #tidytuesday
7:30 - 8:00 pm Discussion

This is a great opportunity to meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build up your GitHub/Twitter/data science portfolio!

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together!

What should I bring?
Please bring your own laptop (fully-charged!) and all learning materials you want to use. If you have time, please look at the data set beforehand and think about some questions you'd like to answer with it.

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** We'll send out an email to members who have RSVP 'Yes' the day before this event.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: RStudioConf2020 Watch Party
description:
#RStudioConf2020 was held in San Francisco in back in January and at the time lots of R-Ladies chapters around the world ran events where members got together and watched the live stream of the keynotes/talks together. Unfortunately for Sydney, the time zone difference was not compatible with running a live event, so now that all the recorded talks are online, we have decided to run a watch party event after the fact.

Use this form to vote for your favourite keynotes/talks. We will break into groups and have several talks running at the same time.

http://tinyurl.com/RLadiesSydneyWatchParty

Our co-founder Dani Navarro, who attended the conference in person, is also going to tell us about her experience and what makes the RStudioConf experience unique.

title: Spatial data analysis with R [cancelled]
description:
***********
Due to the COVID-19 situation we are cancelling this event.
***********
In this session we have a special international guest!
Dr Reka Solymosi who is a Lecturer in Quantitative Methods at the University of Manchester.

Reka I will talk about how she uses R as a GIS for spatial data analysis. Her main areas of research focus on data about crime, policing, and people's perceptions of place. She will cover descriptive analysis, making thematic and point maps, and some spatial statistics.

Come with your own computer if you want to test this workflow. You will learn about packages such as sf, tmap, leaflet, spatstat and probably some more...!

For more info look at her beautiful R website rekadata.site

We look forward to seeing you there!

R-Ladies Brisbane

By taking part in an R-Ladies Brisbane event you grant the community organisers full rights to use the images resulting from the photography/video filming/media, and any reproductions or adaptations of the images for publicity, fund-raising or other purposes to help achieve the community‚Äôs aims. Code of Conduct: R-Ladies Brisbane is dedicated to providing a welcoming and harassment-free event experience for everyone, regardless of gender, gender identity and expression, age, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, ethnicity, or religion (or lack thereof). We do not tolerate harassment of event participants in any form, for any event venue, including talks, workshops, parties, Twitter and other online media.

Community Policies: Please note, cis men are welcome to join our meetups when they come as a guest of a woman participant or they bring a woman with them. We highly encourage speakers and teachers at R-Ladies Brisbane events to be of minority genders.

Find us on Twitter @rladiesbrisbane for more information on news, presentations and code!

title: Code-RLadies March Lightning Talk & Workshop - Now Virtual!
description:
Update - We're now virtual! For the meeting, simply join us on Zoom: https://zoom.us/j/460649757

====

Our March Lighting Talk: **Possibilities on Interactive Dashboards and Business Intelligence with R and Shiny**, with Krista Galyen.

Our March Workshop Focus: **All things 'Projects'** - what are they and how are they used to help you work?

======

COVID-19 PANDEMIC UPDATE:

Because of the COVID-19 pandemic and the social distancing requirements the pandemic necessitates, the Code-RLadies meeting scheduled for Tuesday, March 24th will be held remotely.

Hope, Krista, and Linda, the three founders, are working to make arrangements for this meeting. We will post information on how to access the remote meeting as soon as we have completed the arrangements.

We're looking for a member to volunteer to give a short 15 to 20 minute presentation on how to use RStudio projects to facilitate workflows. You don't have to be an expert to share your knowledge. If you are interested, please post your interest on the Code-RLadies Slack #meeting_announcements channel. If you need access to the Code-RLadies Slack, please email LandonPhD@ResearchCommunique.com.

Decisions about how to hold the April and May meetings will be made in the future. We are working closely with REDI during the pandemic.

Please pass the word about Code-RLadies. We'd love to "see" some new faces.

======

What are Lightning talks? Lightning talks are quick, 5-minute mini-presentations that are showing the art of the possible. They increase awareness and excitement about possibilities. If you want to present a future Lightning Talk, contact us!

What are Workshops? Our workshops help Code-RLadies gather together, network, and learn from each other. Our workshops cover the bulk of the meeting. We believe in being hands-on! Are you interested in leading or participating in a workshop? Contact us!

title: #HowTo Version Control/Git (virtual meeting)
description:
=====================================================
Topic: RLEL: #HowTo Version Control/Git
Time: Mar 23, 2020 06:00 PM EST

Log into Slack: https://rladies-eastlansing.slack.com
(Channels: #howto-vc & #2020-git)
Join Zoom Meeting: https://msu.zoom.us/j/460485077
=====================================================

Learn how to use Git (version control software) to manage your R scripts and other collaborative coding projects.

###############
WHO is this for?
###############
- If you are new to Git & are short-budgeted on time!
- If you'd like to start using version control w/o learning all the command line details first!!
- If you've ever wished there was a way to "track changes" or collaborate on a single script just like you can for google docs.
* If any of this is true, this help session might be for you!

#####
PLAN
#####
Before the meetup:
- Go through the slides and the tutorial included (See MATERIALS section)
- Post your VC/Git questions in the Slack channels #howto-vc & #2020-git (https://rladies-eastlansing.slack.com)

During the meetup:

- Discuss widely applicable Qs via Zoom for everyone's benefit

###########
GITHUB

Slack channels + Zoom for Q&A; live interaction

SETUP INSTRUCTIONS (** Before the meetup)

title: Introduction to data management in R - part 1
description:
Hi R-Ladies!

We are going to be holding our first R workshop in about two weeks. For this workshop, Soane Mota is going to be giving an introduction to working with databases, exploring data frames, and querying data in R. This workshop is intended for beginners, but everyone is welcome!

Soane is a Data Scientist with a Bachelor's degree in Statistics. She is studying for a Master's degree in Data Science, is the organizer of the Women's Data Science study group, and a co-organizer of the R-Ladies Calgary chapter. She has been using R for over 15 years and developed the second R manual in Portuguese when she was an undergrad student back in 2004.

Location: Room 3-10 B meeting room at the Central Library

Please bring your laptop with R and Rstudio installed.

Hope to see you soon!

******************************************************************************
R-Ladies welcomes members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling. Our community is designed to develop our members' R skills & knowledge through social, collaborative learning & sharing. Supporting minority identity access to STEM skills & careers, the Free Software Movement, and contributing to the global R community!
This is a local chapter of R-Ladies Global, an organisation that promotes gender diversity in the R community worldwide. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R. As a founding principle, there is no cost or charge to participate in any of our R-Ladies communities around the world.
We are part of Global R-Ladies group. You can access our presentations, R scripts, and Projects on our Github account and follow us on twitter to stay up to date about R-Ladies news!
Website: https://www.rladies.org
Twitter: @RLadiesGlobal ( https://twitter.com/RLadiesGlobal )
Github: https://github.com/rladies
******************************************************************************

title: Meetup #7: Kako izgleda radni dan jednog Data Analyst - a?
description:
Pozivamo vas na predavanje Bojane Soro, Data Analyst-a u firmi Content Insights, koje ƒáe vam pomoƒái da lak≈°e razumete radne zadatke jedanog Data Analyst-a. Odgovoriƒáemo na pitanja poput:

Koje su prednosti rada u R-u?
Koje pakete R-a koristi Data Analyst?
Da li pored R-a mogu biti korisni neki softveri za vizualizaciju, poput Tableau, i za≈°to?

Nakon predavanja sledi radionica kratkog pregleda znanja koje smo stekli na predhodnim radionicama. Ovaj osvrt ƒáe nam pripremiti Marija Dokaza.

Kome je namenjeno
Predavanje je namenjeno svima koji su zainteresovani da nauƒçe R. Potpunim poƒçetnicima u programiranju kao i onima koji to nisu.

Predavaƒçi

Bojana Soro je master primenjene matematike u oblasti finansija. Zavrsila je Prirodno-matematicki fakultet na Departmanu za matematiku u Novom Sadu. Trenutno radi na poziciji Data Analyst u firmi Content Insights gde svakodnevno analizira i vizualizuje podatake. Primenom statistickih metoda za analizu generi≈°e poslovne izvestaje i interpretira trendove i obrazace u slozenim skupovima podataka. Pored toga ona je clanica R Ladies Novi Sad, kao i Data Science Srbija.

Marija Dokoza je zavr≈°ila master primenjene matematike, matematike finansija, na Prirodno-matematiƒçkom fakultetu u Novom Sadu. Svoju poslovnu karijeru je zapoƒçela kao praktikant, a potom nastavila kao istra≈æivaƒç u kompaniji Advanced Risk and Portfolio Menagement. ARPM je online platforma za uƒçenje finansijske matematike, te je Marija kao praktikant imala zadatak da pseudo kodove napise u programskom jeziku R, a kao istra≈æivaƒç je radila na dokumentaciji, teoriji, kao i vizualizaciji koje su u sklopu same platforme.

Prijava

Zbog ograniƒçenog broja mesta prijava je obavezna.
Na predavanje mo≈æete poneti laptop sa instaliranim R-om i RStudio-m. U toku radionice oni koji imaju svoj set podataka, mogu ga otvoriti i dobiti uputstva za dalju analizu, a ukoliko ste od onih koji nam se prvi put prikljuƒçuju dobiƒáete sva poƒçetna upustva za uƒçenje R-a.

title: Books In Bars - How Charts Lie
description:
Spend Friday night discussing How Charts Lie (https://www.amazon.com/How-Charts-Lie-Getting-Information/dp/1324001569).

A leading data visualization expert explores the negative‚Äïand positive‚Äïinfluences that charts have on our perception of truth.

We‚Äôve all heard that a picture is worth a thousand words, but what if we don‚Äôt understand what we‚Äôre looking at? Social media has made charts, infographics, and diagrams ubiquitous‚Äïand easier to share than ever. We associate charts with science and reason; the flashy visuals are both appealing and persuasive. Pie charts, maps, bar and line graphs, and scatter plots (to name a few) can better inform us, revealing patterns and trends hidden behind the numbers we encounter in our lives. In short, good charts make us smarter‚Äïif we know how to read them.

However, they can also lead us astray. Charts lie in a variety of ways‚Äïdisplaying incomplete or inaccurate data, suggesting misleading patterns, and concealing uncertainty‚Äïor are frequently misunderstood, such as the confusing cone of uncertainty maps shown on TV every hurricane season. To make matters worse, many of us are ill-equipped to interpret the visuals that politicians, journalists, advertisers, and even our employers present each day, enabling bad actors to easily manipulate them to promote their own agendas.

In How Charts Lie, data visualization expert Alberto Cairo teaches us to not only spot the lies in deceptive visuals, but also to take advantage of good ones to understand complex stories. Public conversations are increasingly propelled by numbers, and to make sense of them we must be able to decode and use visual information. By examining contemporary examples ranging from election-result infographics to global GDP maps and box-office record charts, How Charts Lie demystifies an essential new literacy, one that will make us better equipped to navigate our data-driven world.

PS Please contact the organizer if you need support finding the book.

title: The first of 2020: upskilling and ggplot2
description:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
PLEASE NOTE

Due to the recent Covid-19 developments & to take care of the safety of the community, we have decided to postpone the event until further notice.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hello RLadiesCPH!

We are back to bring you the very best for your upskilling/visualization new years' R-esolutions (pun intended).

Please set aside 20th of March for an evening of upskilling advice & intro to visualization with ggplot2.

Space is limited to 30 attendees so hurry up & reserve your post!

A special thanks goes to Carve Consulting (https://www.carve.dk/) for providing us with the venue & sponsoring food/drinks.

**Agenda**

17:30-17:40 Welcome

17:40 - 18:20 Sarah Tomori Oyebo, (Consultant, Carve Consulting, https://www.linkedin.com/in/sarahtomorioyebo/) on her learning experience with professional ML certifications.

Sarah Tomori Oyebo has a masters degree in Accounting, Strategy and Control from Copenhagen Business School. She spent majority of the second year of her masters in South Africa and Nigeria, where she mainly focused on the area of finance- and investment. She now works full-time as a management consultant at Carve Consulting.

Her presentation is about her learning experience during the professional certificate program from Harvard that she recently completed. The program contained 9 courses ranging from R Basics, Data Visualisation, Productivity Tools to Machine Learning and final projects where she had to apply the skills obtained through the program.

18:20 - 18:40 Sandwiches and networking.

18:40 - 19:20 Thomas Lin Pedersen (Software Engineer, RStudio, https://twitter.com/thomasp85) Getting Comfortable with ggplot2.

ggplot2 is one of the most popular plotting frameworks (both in R and beyond). One of the reasons for its success is the clear and descriptive syntax based on the grammar of graphics. This syntax is quite foreign though, and getting started with ggplot2 can thus feel very daunting. In this talk Thomas hopes to give you the required momentum to get over the initial learning hill, see the reason in the syntax, and learn the underlying logic of the system. The talk will be very practical and take root in a series of code examples where we will talk about different aspects of the API that are in play.

19:20 - 19:30 Wrapping up.

Looking forward to seeing you soon!

RLadiesCPH

title: [ONLINE] Scalable Automatic Machine Learning in R with H2O with Erin LeDell
description:
**UPDATE** We are moving this event online, at the same time and day. We will send a Zoom link for the call day prior to the event. Hope you can join us online!

Dr. Erin LeDell is the Chief Machine Learning Scientist at H2O.ai, where she leads the development of an open-source, automatic machine learning (AutoML) platform. Before joining H2O.ai, she worked as a data scientist and software engineer and founded DataScientific, Inc. She‚Äôs also the founder of the non-profit Women in Machine Learning & Data Science (WiMLDS.org) organization and co-founder of the R-Ladies Global organization. She received her Ph.D. from UC Berkeley where her research focused on machine learning and statistical computing.

**Scalable Automatic Machine Learning in R with H2O**

The focus of this presentation is scalable and automatic machine learning in R using the H2O machine learning platform. H2O is an open-source, distributed machine learning platform is designed to scale to very large datasets that may not fit into RAM on a single machine. We will provide a brief overview of the field of Automatic Machine Learning, followed by a detailed look inside H2O‚Äôs AutoML algorithm. H2O AutoML provides an easy-to-use interface that automates data pre-processing, training and tuning a large selection of candidate models (including multiple stacked ensemble models for superior model performance), and due to the distributed nature of the H2O platform, H2O AutoML can scale to very large datasets. The result of the AutoML run is a ‚Äúleaderboard‚Äù of H2O models which can be easily exported for use in production. R code examples are available on GitHub for participants to follow along on their laptops.

--

Q: Are men welcome to attend this event?
A: Our primary mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. ***As such, we strongly encourage that all men who attend this event have a female or non-binary sponsor. Please contact mine@rladies.org if you have questions.***

Additionally, please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

title: Career Series Part II: Our Best Resource is Each Other, A Q&A Panel
description:
R-Ladies Chicago is proud to host the next segment in our three-part Career Series! Join us on Wednesday, March 18 at Groupon for a Q&A panel discussion! We are happy to welcome our own co-organizer Kristi Angel as well as Ging Cee Ng and Christina Maimone to participate in a Q&A discussion on their data science experience in experimentation, industry, and academia respectively. This panel will be moderated by co-organizer Scarlett Winters, and guests will have the opportunity to submit questions in real time. Don't miss this great opportunity to learn from three data scientists across disciplines and build your network along the way.

---------
Schedule
6:00 - 6:30 -- Getting settled in, food and drinks
6:30 - 6:45 -- Intros & Announcements
6:45 - 7:30 -- Panel Discussion
7:30 - 8:00 -- Socializing/Networking/Hanging out/Chillin'
---------

Q: Are men welcome to attend this event?
A: Our primary mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. ***As such, we strongly encourage that all men who attend this event have a female or non-binary sponsor. Please contact chicago@rladies.org if you have questions.***

Additionally, please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

‚Ä¢ What to bring
A laptop! Bring a friend or co-worker too!

‚Ä¢ Important to know

- Please include your last name in your Meetup profile if you haven't, or include it in the RSVP question to ensure secured entry into the Groupon building!

- We expect all attendees to abide & be governed by our community code of conduct. Please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

Thank you to Groupon for sponsoring us!

title: Sports Statistics, Advancing Your Career in 2020, & R Adoption in the Enterprise
description:
# Schedule
Tuesday, March 17th, 6:30-8:30pm
6:30 - [Online Networking Activity] Zoom Breakout Rooms
6:55 - Announcements
7:00 - [Career Corner] Advancing Your Career in 2020 & R Adoption in the Enterprise
7:20 - 10-Minute Break
7:30 - [R Time] A Sports Statistics Show and Tell
8:30 - Meeting Adjourned

# Meeting Location
Out of an abundance of caution regarding COVID-19 and in order to prioritize the health and safety of everyone who attends our events, the March 17th meeting will be held ONLINE using Zoom.

The meeting link will be sent to registered attendees.
Please use the RSVP button to register!

# Presentations
[Career Corner] Advancing Your Career in 2020 & R Adoption in the Enterprise
Speaker: Louis Columbus

[R Time] A Sports Statistics Show and Tell
Speaker: Jason Wilson, PhD
Abstract:
The contents of this presentation will be drawn from the qopbaseball.com project which began in 2010, two years after I completed my Ph.D in Statistics. It originated with a clever student's IntroStat class final project! The research consists of 1 patent-pending statistical model for calculating the quality of a baseball pitch, 8 million Major League Baseball (MLB) pitches calculated, 12 thousand lines of R code, 15 MLB teams consulted, and 1 active Twitter handle @qopbaseball. In the first part of the presentation (~30min.), I will tell the origin story and development, with special attention given to the R work and lessons learned along the way. The second part of the presentation (~20min.) will be guided according to audience interest. I will take questions on any aspects of the project. I will have code and data on hand for demonstration. Sample data will be provided for audience explorations.

# Live-streaming & Meeting Materials
- All registered attendees will receive a Zoom link to join the meeting. Please see the information above.
- All materials will be sent out and posted on our GitHub (https://github.com/rladies-irvine) after the event.
- The recording of the meeting will be sent out and posted on our YouTube Channel (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIbS1KNK7jbcbQVNt7lF62A) after the event.

title: Qualitative analysis in R ~ Now a VIRTUAL Meetup!
description:
Happening tonight! Mary Painter will lead our first ever online R-Ladies St. Louis Meetup for our very first *qualitative* workshop.

Materials for the Meetup are at https://github.com/rladiesstl/meetupMar2020

The most important things to do before the Meetup so you can follow along:

(1) Install RQDA with dependencies (can take time!)
(2) Download and save the files from the GitHub repository to a folder you can find

How to download and save all the files from GitHub:

(1) Go to the repository https://github.com/rladiesstl/meetupMar2020
(2) Click on Clone or download
(3) Choose Download ZIP
(4) Once download is complete, extract the files to a location you can find

If you already downloaded before 3/17/2020, please note some minor revisions to the first code chunk in the R Markdown file and edit your file or re-download this file.

If you have extra time, open the TMandTidyText.Rmd file from the downloaded materials and change the file paths on lines 15 and 42 to the location where you saved everything for this Meetup.

Reminder: R looks for forward slashes / in file paths! (not \)

Mary Painter is a doctoral candidate in political science at the University of Missouri St. Louis.

title: Now virtual meetup: R-Ladies Baltimore -- Wrangling characters and strings in R!
description:
**Please note this event was originally canceled in light of COVID-19 precautions, but we decided to make it VIRTUAL because of the great demand! Please join us on Zoom on Tuesday at 12pm (details below)**

R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is the local Baltimore chapter for the larger R-Ladies global organization (rladies.org) to promote gender diversity in the R community.

The next event is Tuesday March 17, 2020 from 12-1:30pm (virtual meetup on Zoom). We will have a presentation from Carrie Wright (https://carriewright11.github.io) on using the stringr (https://stringr.tidyverse.org) package from the tidyverse (https://www.tidyverse.org) to wrangle characters and strings in R.

WHO is this for?
- If you are new to R & are short-budgeted on time!
- If you work with data in R that have characters or strings!
- If you want to work with data that have characters or strings, but not sure what to do with it!

title: R-Ladies Columbus Monthly Meetup
description:
Sentiment Analysis!
___________________________________________________________________________________
The Objective is to create a neural network that can predict if a given movie review is positive or negative. This type of computation is also called Sentiment Analysis.

I will be working with ‚ÄúIMDB data-set‚Äù, a set of 50,000 reviews from the Internet Movie Database. They are split into 25,000 reviews for training and 25,000 reviews for testing, each set consisting in 50% negative and 50% positive reviews.

I will use Keras library to build neural network and walk you through building and training model, model tuning with different hyper-parameter (Optimizer, Loss Function, No. of layers, epoch, batch_size ). I will try and improve the accuracy of model by experimenting with different hyper-parameters.

Please come with a machine that can access rstudio.cloud. We will share link to project prior to session.

As always pizza and soft drinks will be available courtesy of our great local supporter, the Columbus Collaboratory.

Parking: Park in any spot marked "Reserved for the Columbus Collaboratory". There should be more than enough available- all are free. If you find that these spots are filled - park anywhere in surrounding lots See pics below for directions.

title: R-Ladies - ggplot tutorial with Marguerite Mauritz
description:
A note from Marguerite:

Hi Rladies participants,

I will be demonstrating some uses of ggplot, one of R‚Äôs graphing packages. I‚Äôll give a short intro and then we‚Äôll do a code-along so that everyone can do their own typing.
We will make a few basic figures and then experiment with customizing to make them pretty.
Some code will be pre-written to make it easier to keep up, and some parts you will have to fill in.

To prepare, please pre-load the Tidyverse package in R, on a WiFi connection.

# Tidyverse has a number of basic packages that all load together using the command:
install.packages(‚Äútidyverse‚Äù)
library(tidyverse)

Check that you definitely have:
ggplot2
dplyr
tidyr
readr
On the day of the workshop, we will have the code template and data on USB drives so that you can easily load it to your computer offline. We will use some data that from my research in the Chihuahuan desert looking at rainfall and how water it moves through the soil. It‚Äôs for demonstration purposes only and I think has many features that would appear in other data problems.

Tidyverse is a nice set of packages that work together to make coding and data structure smoother.
More information about Tidyverse is here:
https://www.tidyverse.org/packages/

title: March meetup - data wrangling using the tidyverse
description:
This will be a tutorial session where you can improve your R skills! Please bring a laptop. This meetup will be suitable both for beginners and intermediate R users.

We will work with tidyverse packages and learn how to do data wrangling in R, for example how to change the format of your data, how to combine different dataframes, summarising your data, and dealing with factor levels.

We will meet at 6pm, and then everyone can work on the tutorials. Help will be available.

Please have R and RStudio installed on your laptop, and install the tidyverse (install.packages("tidyverse") ). There will be only limited sockets at the venue, so please charge your laptop before the event.

Location: The Greenhouse, ground floor of Northumbria University Students‚Äô Union.

If you have any questions, comments or suggestions, you can email us at newcastle@rladies.org

Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's R Ladies Meetup: Introduction to R Shiny!

** Please bring your laptops & cash for beer donations!**

This month our very own Lisa Moller will be giving us a tutorial on how to build an R Shiny app from scratch. Lisa has been learning Shiny over the last few months and she's excited to share what she's learned with us!

title: Data Visualization - Intro to ggplot2
description:
Come join us for our first meetup of 2020!

In this workshop we will be learning the basics of ggplot2 with Emma Garlock.

If you were thinking of participating in the Datajam (https://www.vancouverdatajam.ca/#) we are organizing this would be a good additional workshop to go to!

To confirm your spot, please get a ticket on eventbrite:
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/data-visualization-intro-to-ggplot2-tickets-94779071755

About our speaker Emma Garlock:
I am a first year Masters Student in Dr. Fiona Brinkman‚Äôs lab at Simon Fraser University in the MBB department. I am part of the SFU/UBC joint bioinformatics program. I am originally from Halifax, and completed my BSc. Honours Biochemistry at Mount Allison University in May 2019. While on the east coast my research focused on using SNPs to identify potential virulence factors in lobster pathogens. My current research focuses on identifying correlations between early life exposures and dysbioisis of the gut microbiome.

******
About the workshop & instructions:

-Please expect a hands-on session in a friendly and laid-back atmosphere where we all encouraged to learn together.
- All levels are welcome, but be prepared that we created this with beginners in mind. You should be familiar with R and RStudio.
- Install R: https://mirror.its.sfu.ca/mirror/CRAN/
- Install RStudio (choose the Desktop version): https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/#download

- Pack your laptop

**********************IMPORTANT************************

1. Bring your LAPTOP

2. If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

3. Who is this allowed to attend the workshop?
Everyone is welcome to join us at our events and to be a part of our mission to empower gender minorities with the skills and knowledge to code in one of the top programming language in data science, which is R.

To fulfill this mission we do ask participants to respect a focus on the encouragement and support for women and non-binary people during our events.

See you there!

Raissa, Lucia, Jasmine, & Lisa

*****SPONSORS *****
Thanks to Mobify for their support!

title: Segundo Encuentro R-Ladies Medell√≠n: Visualizaci√≥n de datos con ggplot2
description:
Una de las habilidades m√°s importantes para la ciencia de datos es la creaci√≥n de gr√°ficos √∫tiles y llamativos que permitan comunicar informaci√≥n significativa contenida en nuestras bases de datos. ggplot 2 es un paquete de visualizaci√≥n de datos del lenguaje de programaci√≥n R. En este taller usaremos este paquete para analizar una base de datos que corresponde a los resultados de la Encuesta de la Juventud realizada en la Cuidad de Medell√≠n.

Para este taller es necesario traer tu computador y tener previamente instalado R y RStudio. Para mayor informaci√≥n sobre el proceso de instalaci√≥n consulta este link: https://www.datacamp.com/community/news/install-r-and-rstudio-a-step-by-step-guide-for-beginners-q498j0akyh

title: R-Ladies for all! Networking event and Anniversary celebration

title: Introduction to Shiny
description:
Shiny is an R package that makes it easy to build interactive web apps straight from R. In this beginner-friendly session, we'll be working through part one of the RStudio shiny tutorial.

https://shiny.rstudio.com/tutorial/

This will be an interactive session so please bring your laptop. Ideally, this should have R and RStudio installed. If you have trouble downloading these, you can use https://rstudio.cloud/. You will also need the shiny R package. Please, install this before coming along to the session. You can do this by running install.packages("shiny") in R.

We will be in Lancaster University Library - Room C135. The session will run from 6pm - 8pm with a short break in the middle. Snacks and soft drinks will be provided.

title: "Totally Tidy Tuning Tools" by Max Kuhn
description:
R-Ladies Miami is excited to present Max Kuhn on March 3, 2020!

Many machine learning models have hyperparameters whose values cannot be analytically estimated from the data. For example, the number of neighbors in a nearest-neighbor classification model. The tidymodels collection or R packages are a tidyverse interface to modeling. In this talk, the new tune package will be introduced. Examples of the tidy interface to model tuning will be demonstrated.

Max Kuhn is a software engineer at RStudio. He is currently working on improving R's modeling capabilities. He was a Senior Director of Nonclinical Statistics at Pfizer Global R&D in Connecticut. He was applying models in the pharmaceutical and diagnostic industries for over 18 years. Max has a Ph.D. in Biostatistics.

Max is the author of numerous R packages for techniques in machine learning and reproducible research and is an Associate Editor for the Journal of Statistical Software. He, and Kjell Johnson, wrote the book Applied Predictive Modeling, which won the Ziegel award from the American Statistical Association, which recognizes the best book reviewed in Technometrics in 2015. Their latest book, Feature Engineering and Selection, was published in 2019.

title: Lightning Talks
description:
Lightning Talks are quick 5-minute presentations on whatever you like. Really - anything. All levels of R proficiency are welcome! All topics are welcome! You can present on something you know well, something you‚Äôre in the midst of learning, or something you‚Äôd like to do and are just getting started with. These talks are a great way to get to know each other and get to know the work we all do, as well as get advice, support, and validation from your fellow R users. Please present! It‚Äôs a lot of fun in a safe space.

You can choose to have slides (e.g. PowerPoint) or live code in R or talk off the dome if you really want to! We use HDMI to connect to the library computer, and you can choose to send us slides in advance, bring materials on a USB, or connect your own device.

Come! Talk! It‚Äôs fun!

If you‚Äôre interested in presenting, please fill out this survey (https://forms.gle/TQWiRGVbj2YxpUd89) so we have a sense of who is presenting and what we‚Äôll hear. If you‚Äôre thinking about it but aren‚Äôt sure, reach out to us to chat about it! We‚Äôre easiest to contact on Twitter or via email.

For presenters and non-presenters alike, please RSVP on our Meetup. See you there!

title: Hackathon - finding new insights from publicly available datasets
description:
Hey everyone,

Let's get together for another Hackathon! The goal is to use publicly available datasets to extract new insights. It's pretty amazing how much we can learn with some very basic exploratory data analysis in R, from there, the sky is the limit.

We'll start with Elke giving us an example of how she did a really awesome project on small business in San Diego using data from California's Employment Development Department.
If we have time, Juliana will also give an example of how you can use natural language processing with freely available abstracts from scientific papers to learn a bunch of new sciency things!

After that we'll divide into small groups to analyze other datasets or further explore one of the topics above.
You're welcome to use any dataset that interests you. Try google dataset search to see if anything out there sparks your curiosity. Kaggle also has loads of cool datasets available.

We'll end the evening sharing what the different groups have done.

Hope to see you all soon!

You can find links to the resources mentioned above below:
California EDD Labor Market Information Resources and Data: https://www.labormarketinfo.edd.ca.gov/LMID/Size_of_Business_Data.html
Biomedical natural language processing datasets and models: http://bio.nlplab.org/
Google's dataset search: https://datasetsearch.research.google.com/
Kaggle datasets: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets

title: Lascia Excel a casa e vieni a scoprire R con R-Ladies Bari
description:
Bentornati Community R-Ladies Bari

Il prossimo evento

Sei un utente Excel e hai paura di immergerti in R? sei fortunata/o! R-Ladies Bari √® qui per sconfiggere quelle paure! Con questo incontro, forniremo risorse ed esempi di cui hai bisogno per iniziare a fare alcune delle cose di base che sei abituata/o a fare in Excel in R.
Il prossimo evento, che si terr√† il 28 Febbraio presso IC406 (Bari) dalle 18:00 alle 20:30, si focalizzer√† su lasciare a casa Excel ed iniziare ad utilizzare R .

Cosa imparerai?

Quest'evento, e il successivo (3 aprile 2020), saranno interamente dedicati a introdurre R e Rstudio. Vogliamo offrire un'opportunit√† a tutti i beginners di R di imparare le basi per poter poi crescere insieme nei prossimi mesi.
In questo primo evento ci occuperemo di gestione e creazione di dataset per fare analisi statistiche. Nell'evento successivo scopriremo come visualizzare i risultati e scrivere report di facile consumo attraverso R.
Negli ultimi 30 minuti faremo networking per conoscerci meglio. IC406 ha gentilmente deciso di offrire ai partecipanti snack e bibite per rendere questo momento sociale pi√π piacevole (se avete allergie importanti, scriveteci a sara.iacozza.si@gmail.com).

Cosa devi portare con te?

Chi siamo e a chi sono rivolti i nostri eventi?

RLadies Bari √® un gruppo locale che si rif√† a RLadies Global (https://rladies.org/about-us/), un‚Äôorganizzazione internazionale non-profit con circa 60.000 membri in 46 diversi paesi del mondo. Lo scopo dell‚Äôorganizzazione √® di promuovere diversit√† ed equit√† di genere nella comunit√† di utenti di R.
Se utilizzi, o vorresti imparare ad utilizzare R, questo √® il gruppo giusto! Tutti sono benvenuti gratuitamente, previa registrazione a , ed hanno la possibilit√† di imparare in un contesto amicale e di supporto.

title: Tidy up your data science workflow with the tidyverse
description:
Registration to the event is required on Eventbrite: https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/tidy-up-your-data-science-workflow-with-the-tidyverse-tickets-91446038563

RLadies London is excited to present Mine √áetinkaya-Rundel!

About the event
The tidyverse is a coherent system of packages for data manipulation, exploration and visualization that share a common design philosophy.
There are core tidyverse packages that you're likely to use in everyday data analyses, and these include:
- ggplot2
- dplyr
- tidyr
- readr
- purrr
- tibble
- stringr
- forecats
We'll be learning a bit about each of these core packages while demonstrating their functionalities!

About the speaker
Mine is a Senior Lecturer in the School of Mathematics at University of Edinburgh and Data Scientist and Professional Educator at RStudio. Mine‚Äôs work focuses on innovation in statistics and data science pedagogy, with an emphasis on computing, reproducible research, student-centered learning, and open-source education as well as pedagogical approaches for enhancing retention of women and under-represented minorities in STEM. Mine works on integrating computation into the undergraduate statistics curriculum, using reproducible research methodologies and analysis of real and complex datasets. She is a former R-Ladies RTP and a current R-Ladies Edinburgh organizer.

Agenda

18:30 Presentation
19:30 Networking

title: timetrackR and gtsummary
description:
**Meeting location: LMHQ 150 Broadway 20th floor, New York, NY 10038**

Our speakers for the night will be Jessica Lavery and Margie Hannum from Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Jessica will be talking about the timetrackR app. Margie will be discussing the gtsummary package.

Agenda:
6:30-6:55 pm Introductions and Social Time
6:55-7 pm R-Ladies New York Announcements
7-7:10 Sponsor Message from IBM Developer New York
7:10-7:40 It's Time to Shine with timetrackR App, Jessica Lavery
7:40-8:10 Creating publication-ready and reproducible analytical tables with gtsummary, Margie Hannum
8:10-8:30 Networking

Title: It‚Äôs Time to Shine with the timetrackR App
Presenter: Jessica Lavery

Abstract: While tracking time may seem like a mundane task that in and of itself consumes your time, if monitored and assessed regularly it can be useful to create a record of your work and to identify potential areas for improving efficiency. The timetrackR Shiny app provides a high-level summary of active, inactive and upcoming projects, as well as visualizations for the percentage of time spent by project or project investigator, number of hours spent on each project, and a timeline framing each project‚Äôs trajectory from planning through analysis and manuscript preparation. With the option to filter by year, investigator and analyst, the app is versatile enough to use for an individual or for an entire team as well as for use on a regular basis and for year-end or longer-term reviews of how time was spent. I will highlight the key features of the app and demonstrate how to integrate into your current workflow.

Bio: Jessica Lavery is a Biostatistician in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. She has an MS in Biostatistics from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (2014) and as of Fall 2019 is also pursuing a doctorate in public health (DrPH) in Biostatistics at Columbia University. Her research focuses primarily on retrospective analyses using institutional and claims data sources. She also serves as the 2019-2020 Volunteer Coordinator for the Caucus for Women in Statistics. Follow her on Twitter @jessicalavs

Title: Creating publication-ready and reproducible analytical tables with gtsummary
Presenter: Margie Hannum

Abstract: A critical aspect of many data analysis projects is presenting tables of summary statistics and regression model results. However, summarizing results into publication-ready tables often requires a lot of extra code to customize (e.g. create reference line for categorical variables, format p-values a certain way, bold variable labels, merge multiple model results into one table, etc.). The {gtsummary} package provides an elegant and flexible way to make summary and analytic tables in R. Written as a companion to the {gt} package from RStudio, the {gtsummary} package summarizes data sets, regression models, and more, using sensible defaults with highly customizable capabilities. It also allows you to pull values straight from these tables for use in inline text so that every portion of your R markdown analysis report is reproducible. This talk will go over the functionality of the {gtsummary} package, and how you can use it to create beautifully formatted, ready-to-share summary and result tables in a single line of R code.

Bio: Margie Hannum is a Biostatistician at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics. Her research collaborations largely involve using multi-modal genomic and single cell data to characterize cancer subpopulations. She contributes to the {gtsummary} package and uses it every day in her analysis pipelines. Twitter: @Margaret_Hannum

title: Putting your R-code into production using Docker containers
description:
Making a quick script for a model or visual in R is something we do everyday. But what if we have some kind of script, model or visual that we would like to use many times a day or make available in a robust way to many users? That's what production is about!
Nowadays, putting code into production, is a complicated story of containers, pipelines, infrastructure, clusters etc. We are going to learn the basics of how to "containerize" your code for production-ready R-coding using Docker-containers. This skill will make you ready to discuss on how to bring your R-code into production within your IT department or in any cloud-environment. We will work in small groups and go step by step so you are ready to rock your code in production!

PROGRAM
---------------
18:00 - 18:30 Welcome & Food
18:30 - 18:45 Intro RLadies and SiaPartners
18:45 - 19:30 Introduction to R in Production
19:30 - 19:45 Break
19:45 - 20:30 Workshop dockerize your R code
20:30 - 21:00 Drinks & Networking

IMPORTANT
For security reasons we need to provide a list of participants. Please use this form to submit your name https://forms.gle/916kPtLAh6qx4n9r9 .

ABOUT INDERDEEP
--------------------------
https://www.linkedin.com/in/inderdeep-singh/
Inderdeep holds a BSc degree in Econometrics from the Free University of Amsterdam and a MSc degree in Econometrics from the Erasmus University of Rotterdam. She has more than 3 years of experience applying data science methods in the insurance industry, lease companies, health care and banking industry. Inderdeep is part of the Data Science Center of Excellence at Sia Partners Amsterdam.

ABOUT SIAPARTNERS
------------------------------
https://sia-partners.com/
Sia Partners is a next-generation consulting firm focused on delivering superior value and tangible results to its clients as they navigate the digital revolution. Our global footprint and our expertise in more than 30 sectors and services allow us to enhance our clients' businesses worldwide. We guide their projects and initiatives in strategy, business transformation, IT & digital strategy, and Data Science. As the pioneer of Consulting 4.0, we develop consulting bots and integrate AI in our solutions.

REQUIREMENTS
----------------------
You should be comfortable to work with R (medium/advanced).

We will use Docker during the meetup. Try if you can install docker on your laptop to get the most out of the event. You need Docker Desktop to work along with the tutorial. https://www.docker.com/products/docker-desktop
We can also help at the beginning to setup docker with you, so pass by at the beginning if you need some help. :)

CODE OF CONDUCT
----------------------------
We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct. Anyone who violates this community's Code of Conduct will be refused entry, expelled, and/or any other action deemed appropriate by the Organizer, regardless of event registration, meetup membership or other condition. We are emphatically queer and trans-friendly. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn.

title: Career Series Part 1: Using R to Land the Job, a Resume Building Tutorial
description:
Welcome to the kick-off of our three-part career series! Over the next three months, we will host events to further develop your skillset and data science network.

Whether or not you're on the job hunt, your resume is an extension of your professional self, so it is important to keep your resume fresh. For our kick-off, our co-organizer Scarlett Winters will lead a tutorial on how to build your resume using pagedown. You will walk away from this tutorial with the skills to prove to employers you know how to code in R well before your interview!

*Prerequisites:
We ask that R-Ladies who are interested in this event please install:
- R:
https://www.r-project.org/

- R Studio:
https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

- Pagedown package, information found here: https://github.com/rstudio/pagedown
https://pagedown.rbind.io/

Additionally, if you have no background with Git or Github, we *strongly* recommend you take a look at modules 4-8 of the free Happy Git with R book (https://happygitwithr.com/github-acct.html) and follow the instructions to get yourself set up ahead of time to reduce pain the day of. If you need help with this, please come early so we can help you in person.

The repo for this event can be found here, and will be updated with more information as we get closer to the event date:
https://github.com/rladies-chicago/2020-02-26-pagedown-tutorial

---------
Schedule
6:00 - 6:30 -- Getting settled in, food and drinks
6:30 - 6:45 -- Intros & Announcements
6:45 - 7:30 -- Pagedown Tutorial
7:30 - 8:00 -- Socializing/Networking/Hanging out/Chillin'
---------

Q: Are men welcome to attend this event?
A: Our primary mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. ***As such, we strongly encourage that all men who attend this event have a female or non-binary sponsor. Please contact chicago@rladies.org if you have questions.***

Additionally, please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

‚Ä¢ What to bring
A laptop! Bring a friend or co-worker too!

‚Ä¢ Important to know
We expect all attendees to abide & be governed by our community code of conduct. Please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

title: (late) Tidy Tuesday :)
description: Tidy Tuesday is back this semester. Due to time conflict, TidyTuesday will happen on Wednesday @ 5pm room 2113 Snedecor (ISU campus)

title: How to use GitHub with R
description:
You will learn how to use GitHub with R!
Speaker: Stephanie Reinders

Everyone is welcome

title: Kayce Hyde talks through Data Imputation
description: In Memorial Hall 253

title: Tidy Tuesday - Come and practice your R skills
description:
LAST TIDY TUESDAY!!!

After one and half month of uninterrupted weekly meetups to analyze data we are approaching the end of the Tidy Tuesday Meetings, just before the first anniversary of R-Ladies!!!
If you have not participated yet, do not miss this event! It is a great opportunity to meet us in an informal environment and practice your R-Skills independently of your expertise (from totally beginners to experts). And if you have been regularly coming, do not miss this last Tidy Tuesday Evening!

Hope to see you there!

We will use the data from Tidy Tuesday as an excuse to work with R. We will meet to work independently using the same data-set. Each one can choose which analysis to perform or which tools to use (you can already think what you want to practice or learn). We will do this together to have the opportunity to ask others and because coding together is fun!

So far the R-Ladies Freiburg have been working really hard in producing super nice plots! The idea of this meeting is to share our knowledge. You can have a look at them on:

https://twitter.com/RLadiesFreiburg

This activity is for everyone, from beginners to experts. You will set your own goal. We will have a coffee (or what ever you prefer) while working together. This way we can have the opportunity to ask others, to share ideas and code!!

It is also a great opportunity to start doing analysis to add to your portfolio on line, so that others know what you can do! Have a look at:

https://github.com/kyla-mcconnell/tidy-tuesday

https://github.com/ichisa/TidyTuesday

IMPORTANT:

Bring your own laptop. Hopefully with enough battery.

title: Analyse your data using GAMs in R ‚Äì All levels welcome!
description:
Have you heard about generalised additive models (GAMs) and would like to know more about how to use them? Come along to this workshop to get an introduction to GAMs: what they are and when and how to use them.

PROGRAMME
Note the different day (Tuesday) and location (Orikami)!

The event will start at 18:30.
Data Scientist Inez Wijnands will start us off with an introduction to the work that Orikami does and then Evelien will tell us all about GAMs!

Inez Wijnands works as a data scientist at Orikami. She studied Artificial Intelligence with a focus on Computational Cognitive Neuroscience at the Radboud University. At Orikami she uses 'AI in healthcare', combining her main interests.

Dr. Evelien Heyselaar is an Assistant Professor in AI and Communication Science at the Radboud University.

Drinks and snacks will be provided by Orikami.

REQUIREMENTS
Don't forget to bring your (fully charged!) laptop with R and R Studio installed.

You can download the materials from: https://github.com/RLadiesNijmegen/GAMMs

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

SPONSORS
We are very grateful to Orikami for sponsoring this event!

venues.name: Orikami Data Science for Healthcare & Lifesciences, Personalized Healthcare

description:

title: First R-Ladies Meetup: Introduction to the community and R Basics
description:
Welcome to the first event of R-Ladies Gothenburg!

At this first event, which is hosted in collaboration with the Department of Political Science at the University of Gothenburg, we will introduce the R-Ladies community and review of the main concepts for working with R.

Please bring your computer with R and RStudio installed. If you need help with this step, contact us beforehand or watch this online tutorial: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=orjLGFmx6l4.

Please confirm your attendance here on Meetup and make sure to arrive on time. The doors to the main building automatically lock at 6:30 pm, which means that you will not be able to enter the building unless you have a valid university keycard.

If you have not already responded to our Pre-Meetup Survey, please do so using the following link: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdE11TxP52Vq1Pew_c3dmj-jfPivwNP3NjFnDpB1dToY_xioQ/viewform

Most welcome!

R-Ladies Gothenburg Team
