title: Hacknight at Kakao
description:
About:

A hacknight is a free-style coding environment, where a group of individuals come together to work on various projects in one space, with the purpose to ask one another questions, ranging from specific troubleshooting to conceptual. These projects can be group projects or individual.

Details:

Bring your code and laptop and get ready to enjoy some coffee/hot chocolate and a good working environment.

I will be working on making an R package from code I‚Äôve written over the years. I will be following this tutorial, which anyone can follow step-by-step even without any specific code to add to a package. http://web.mit.edu/insong/www/pdf/rpackage_instructions.pdf

If you do not have a specific project but would like to join, you could start (or finish if you attended the Rladies meetup on Feb 18th) your Tidy Tuesday plots. Tidy Tuesday datasets can be found at https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday and you can follow this vignette from the awesome ggpubr package to make some pretty plots quickly https://rpkgs.datanovia.com/ggpubr/index.html.

For more plotting ideas/vignettes, check out http://www.sthda.com/english/articles/24-ggpubr-publication-ready-plots and built-in datasets are listed here: http://www.sthda.com/english/wiki/r-built-in-data-sets.

title: Code-RLadies February Workshop: R Studio Part 2
description:
Our February 25th workshop will begin with wonderful food and a lightning talk with Linda Landon, Ph.D.

Our February workshop will be focused on all things R Studio. How to use it, how to navigate it, and create some things along the way!

What are Lightning talks? Lightning talks are quick, 5-minute mini-presentations that are showing the art of the possible. They increase awareness and excitement about possibilities. If you want to present a future Lightning Talk, contact us!

What are Workshops? Our workshops help Code-RLadies gather together, network, and learn from each other. Our workshops cover the bulk of the meeting. We believe in being hands-on! Are you interested in leading or participating in a workshop? Contact us!

venues.name: REDI Office in Downtown Columbia, MO

title: Feb meetup: ggWhat to ggplot - a guide to creating powerful visualisations
description:
Data visualisation is one of the most important tools for any person working with data, but often finds itself as an afterthought in both theory and practice of data science. A well designed visual reveals the hidden story behind the data and has the potential to bring about change.

This talk will not only take you through the fundamentals of using the ggplot package to generate visualisations, but also the core principals and best practices needed to make it powerful.

The session is hands-on, so if you want to follow along please install the tidyverse.

Please join us, and the lovely Gemma Dawson as she takes us through this important topic!

Packages:
install.packages("tidyverse")

Please also install the packages below:

library(ggplot2movies) # install.packages("ggplot2movies")
library(cowplot) # install.packages("cowplot")
library(ggrepel) # install.packages("ggrepel")
library(gghighlight) # install.packages("gghighlight")
library(ggedit) # install.packages("ggedit")

title: Tidy Tuesday
description:
Hello RiveRside community ;-)

Come join us for another afternoon of networking and sharing (and pizza!), on Tuesday, February 25th at 5 pm, at Rivera Library 140. This week we will be exploring a recent Tidy Tuesday dataset. Tidy Tuesday is a weekly social data project in R organized by the R4DS Online Learning Community. Come try your hand at wrangling and making a beautiful figure from this dataset to share with us during the meeting, and/or bring your questions. Whether you are new to R or a data scientist, there will be an opportunity for everyone to learn something new. Our lightning talks this week will be presented by UCR's Office of Technology Partnerships (OTP) and they will talk about two exciting OTP programs!

From the Tidy Tuesday website:
"Every week we post a raw dataset, a chart or article related to that dataset, and ask you to explore the data. While the dataset will be 'tamed', it will not always be tidy! As such you might need to apply various R for Data Science techniques to wrangle the data into a true tidy format. The goal of TidyTuesday is to apply your R skills, get feedback, explore other‚Äôs work, and connect with the greater #RStats community! As such we encourage everyone of all skills to participate!"

Since a wide range of skill levels are represented by our group :) we've decided to work with the NFL Stadium Attendance from early February as there's more community posted code for inspiration on twitter (check out #tidytuesday):
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2020/2020-02-04/readme.md

Big thanks to UCR Library, UCR GradQuant, andUCR's Office of Technology Partnerships (OTP) supporting us and this event, and special thanks to our sponsor, The Blackstone LaunchPad powered by Techstars at UCR, for providing the pizza!

See you there!!

title: Data Science Panel
description:
At this event, we'll hear from 4 female data scientists about their career path and the skills they developed for their specialty. Our panelist's have a wide range of experiences. Our panelists also have programming experience in diverse data science languages (not just R!).

Panelist 1 - Dr. Susan Simmons (Professor, Institute for Advanced Analytics)
Panelist 2 - Lisa Smith (Director, Women Who Code Raleigh-Durham)
Panelist 3 - Dr. Lauren Wyatt (Researcher, US Environmental Protection Agency)
Panelist 4 - Caroline Kery (Data Scientist, RTI International)

This event is sponsored by NC State's Institute for Advanced Analytics (https://analytics.ncsu.edu/).

Important to know: Please RSVP to this event so we can plan appropriately. If your plans change, please update your RSVP so others can join in your place.

We will have a light dinner. Donations will be accepted to help cover cost, pay as you are able. If donations exceed costs, money will go to future events.

Parking: Visitors can park in the Poulton Deck or the Partners Way Deck (https://transportation.ncsu.edu/visitor-parking/). Please double check parking signs as there are a few places that do not allow parking after 5pm. Also, do not park in the attached parking deck (Alliance Parking Deck) as it is highly likely your car will be towed.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: Intro to RMarkdown for Reproducible Research
description:
Learn to integrate metadata, text, and code with RMarkdown. This workshop follows the outline from RStudio Education: https://ysc-rmarkdown.netlify.com/materials/

WHO is this for?
- If you are new to R & are short-budgeted on time!
- If you'd like to start working with data in R w/o learning all the programming details first!!
- If you are interested in reproducible research and learning to integrate your code, documentation, and output

title: R-Ladies Jakarta 7th Meetup: introduction to dplyr in R.
description:
Hello again, R enthusiasts!!! We're having out seventh meetup, real soon!

Sunday, 23rd of February 2020 from 10.00-12.30 WIB, at Nutrifood Inspiring Centre, Apartemen Menteng Square Tower A No. AR 12
http://www.nutrifood.co.id/nic/, Jl. Matraman no 30E Jakarta Pusat.

We will show you how R can be used for data cleaning, similar to what you used worksheet for, but this time you can do it with R codes. Interested? Hurry up and register then! as we will together explore a very handy library named 'dplyr'.

"dplyr in R is a grammar of data manipulation, providing a consistent set of verbs that help you solve the most common data manipulation challenges "

Some IMPORTANT stuff:

3. E-mail us at jakarta@rladies.org or tweet to "@rladiesjakarta" for any inquiries regarding this event!

1. Intro to R.pdf

You can download and read the descriptions here: https://github.com/RLadiesJakarta/starter-kit

title: Meetup 3: Introduction to Git
description:
Speaker: Ragini Jain

Ragini is a DevOps automation specialist at Strikr.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Talk description:

Git is a distributed version control system used extensively in Free or Open Source Software (FOSS) projects. It provides remarkable speed, efficiency and support for non-linear workflows.

In the introductory Git session, the attendees will learn capabilities of Git. Working with a new repo, dealing with staging and commits, addressing new requirements in branches, sharing the work and multiple models of merging. We will also discuss about 'fetch and merge' vs 'pull'.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Please bring a fully-charged laptop and a setup will be provided to the attendees to explore git concepts and capabilities.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
To attend, please RSVP. It would be good to keep your RSVP up to date. Please unRSVP, if you realize you can't make it.

description:

title: I'm a Data Scientist, Git me out of here!
description:
Hello lovely people

We're back! Our first Meetup of 2020 is next Thursday.
Shout out to our amazing hosts Women@Workday! <3

We're welcoming back Bruna Wundervald as our speaker. Some of you may remember her great talk on random forests she gave last year.

Bruna and I will give a talk on how data scientists work with Git. You can bring your laptop and follow along, because there will be hands-on elements.

This meetup is aimed at intro/mid-level Data Scientists and Students. You do not need to know R programming to follow along.
We prepared material especially for folks who:
- want to share their work for collaboration with others or to showcase their work
- want to make their results reproducible (especially for science-related cases)
- want to learn R from lots of great resources available on GitHub

We are looking forward to seeing you.

Agenda
6:00-6:30 arrival and networking
6:30-6:45 welcome and announcements
6:45-8:45 talk and demo 'I'm a Data Scientist, Git me out of here!

READ ON IF YOU WANT TO PARTICIPATE IN THE HANDS-ON PART OF THE MEETUP.

- install git (here are instructions for Mac https://rafalab.github.io/dsbook/accessing-the-terminal-and-installing-git.html and Windows https://rafalab.github.io/dsbook/accessing-the-terminal-and-installing-git.html#terminal-on-windows)

title: Leaving academia and diving into data science! Myths, tips and tricks.
description:
In this talk, Erika Braithwaite will discuss some myths about jobs in data science and tricks about how to rebrand yourself if you're leaving academia. Erika will also present some analysis on the 2018 Kaggle Data Scientist Survey to help make talk more data-driven :)

Please come with the most updated version of R and RStudio installed on your laptop. Please see our github page for more details on current and past events, including materials and code! https://github.com/rladies/meetup-presentations_montreal

As usual, snacks and drinks will be provided by our sponsor Upgrade INC.!!

Happy coding :-)

title: Scraping and Visualising Twitter Data with Anna Henschel
description:
In this short, hands-on workshop we are going to scrape and visualize our own Twitter data by understanding the basics of text wrangling and by taking advantage of the amazing {tidytext} and {rtweet} packages. By the end of the workshop, you will be able to see if you tweet mostly positive or negative content, and you will be able to plot the most frequent words in a wordcloud. Don't worry if you do not have your own Twitter account - there will be an alternative provided.

Anna Henschel is a third year PhD candidate at the University of Glasgow, where she conducts research in the Social Brain in Action Lab on the ERC-funded Social Robots project. She has a B.Sc. in Psychology from Konstanz University and a M.Sc. cum laude from the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam in Cognitive Neuropsychology. Her feminist activism and work as a STEM ambassador was recently honoured with the YWCA 30 Under 30 Inspirational Women Scotland award. She uses R in her PhD and also just for fun.

You can find her on Twitter (@AnnaHenschel) and check out the workshop Twitter account (@beautiful_hack).

title: #ShutUpandCode
description:
Learning something new on your own is hard! So lets meet up and learn new R things together.

This month we are getting together at University of Sydney to meet up, shut up (talking is allowed if you are seeking/getting help), and code.

Modelled on the academic writing #ShutUpAndWrite movement (https://thesiswhisperer.com/shut-up-and-write/), the idea is make learning social.

There are only 10 places available at each session, so ONLY RSVP if you are SURE you will come. Please do not take a place from another RLady, and then not turn up.

title: Meetup - Space State Models using R
description:
LIGA DE REGISTRO: https://widscommunityr-usersmeetup.splashthat.com

¬°Bienvenidos a esta comunidad!

Les dejamos informaci√≥n sobre nuestra ponente y coordinadora.

Verenice Amante es actuaria y cient√≠fica de datos egresada del ITAM con especialidad en modelos econometricos din√°micos por la misma escuela y en riesgos financieros por parte de la Universidad Anahuac. Con experiencia de m√°s de diez a√±os en instituciones financieras, y dos de los bancos con mayor presencia en el sistema financiero mexicano. Actualmente trabaja en Monterrey para un banco en proyectos de innovaci√≥n relacionados con estrategias comerciales, el incremento y gesti√≥n de ingresos, comportamiento del cliente, y macroeconom√≠a. Sus especialidades incluyen la miner√≠a de datos, aprendizaje de m√°quina, previsi√≥n financiera, econometr√≠a, y gesti√≥n de riesgos en cr√©ditos de consumo.

Nuestra segunda platica es en colaboraci√≥n con el grupo de R-Users de Monterrey y sera: "Introducci√≥n al aprendizaje por refuerzo en R" con Arturo Victoria egresado de la licenciatura en Matem√°ticas Aplicadas del ITAM, Cient√≠fico de Datos en Banregio Subdirector de Modelos y Metodolog√≠as.

El aprendizaje por refuerzo es un m√©todo de aprendizaje autom√°tico donde el agente recibe una recompensa en su siguiente paso para evaluar su acci√≥n previa. Debido a sus sorprendentes resultados desde el dominio en juegos de Atari hasta el gran logro de DeepMind con MuZero, el aprendizaje por refuerzo se ha convertido en una de las √°reas de investigaci√≥n m√°s populares ya que resuelve un tipo de problema donde la toma de decisiones es secuencial y el objetivo a largo plazo. En esta charla comentaremos sobre los conceptos b√°sicos del aprendizaje por refuerzo, los procesos de decisi√≥n de Markov y un ejemplo de implementaci√≥n en R utilizando las librer√≠as MDPtoolbox y ReinforcementLearning

title: Tidy Tuesday - Come and practice your R skills
description:
Do you want to practice your R-skills? Do you want to improve your abilities to clean, analyse and plot data?

Then this event is what you need! We will use the data from Tidy Tuesday as an excuse to work with R. We will meet to work independently using the same data-set. Each one can choose which analysis to perform or which tools to use (you can already think what you want to practice or learn). We will do this together to have the opportunity to ask others and because coding together is fun!

So far the R-Ladies Freiburg have been working really hard in producing super nice plots! The idea of this meeting is to share our knowledge. You can have a look at them on:

https://twitter.com/RLadiesFreiburg

This activity is for everyone, from beginners to experts. You will set your own goal. We will have a coffee (or what ever you prefer) while working together. This way we can have the opportunity to ask others, to share ideas and code!!

It is also a great opportunity to start doing analysis to add to your portfolio on line, so that others know what you can do! Have a look at:

https://github.com/kyla-mcconnell/tidy-tuesday

https://github.com/ichisa/TidyTuesday

IMPORTANT:

Bring your own laptop. Hopefully with enough battery.

title: Getting started with R
description:
Hey there!

its the beginning of a new year and we are having a session for beginners... This time will be all about learning R :)

*You are already familiar with R*
come by and support the others or come and take the time to learn something you have been meaning to get a handle on for a long time!

*You are new to R and the community*
feel free to join, this is the meet-up for you!

The wonderful Lisa Hehnke (twitter: @dataplanes) will give an "Intro to R" and in our hands-on session you get to try it out yourself. Either join for some exercises or work on your own projects/ideas.

Meet Lisa
*********************************************
She is a researcher turned social data scientist who is working to address current societal challenges in order to make a difference and drive change. After obtaining her Master's degree in politics and public administration with specializations in management and quantitative research methods, Lisa worked as a researcher for computational social science and quantitative data analysis at the Universities of Konstanz, Hamburg, and Bielefeld. She currently develops a decentralized knowledge commons infrastructure with Liberate Science and serves as a steering committee member of the Open Science MOOC to make open the default setting for all global research.

Schedule:
*********************************************
18.30 - Arrival and Welcome
19.00 - Intro to R with Lisa
20.00 - Hands-on session: You can do it
20.30 - Keep going or Mingle

preparation
*********************************************
for the meet-up, try to have R and RStudio installed on your device, so that you are ready to go. If you run into problems, we can sort them out at the venue ;)
If possible, also pre-install these two packages by typing the following code into the console:
install.packages("tidyverse")
install.packages("rtweet")

you already want to get started?
*********************************************
here are some materials with which you can start

install.packages("swirl")
library(swirl)

contact
*********************************************
twitter: @RLadiesBerlin
please get in touch if you have any questions!

********************************************************************************
stay tuned for more details and preparation instructions :)

title: Tidy Tuesday and Pizza at Fred Hutch
description:
Tidy Tuesday is a weekly social data project in R organized by the R4DS Online Learning Community. Join R-Ladies on Tuesday, February 18th to learn more about Tidy Tuesday and to work on this week's project.

From the Tidy Tuesday website:
"Every week we post a raw dataset, a chart or article related to that dataset, and ask you to explore the data. While the dataset will be 'tamed', it will not always be tidy! As such you might need to apply various R for Data Science techniques to wrangle the data into a true tidy format. The goal of TidyTuesday is to apply your R skills, get feedback, explore other‚Äôs work, and connect with the greater #RStats community! As such we encourage everyone of all skills to participate!"

More information and the data for each week is available on the Tidy Tuesday website (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday).

Details:
6pm - 8pm
Fred Hutch Sze Conference Room in the Thomas Building
(Note that this is a different building than past R-Ladies events. See map here for directions: https://www.fredhutch.org/content/dam/www/about-us/contact-us/FredHutch_Map_09_2019.pdf)
Pizza provided by Fred Hutch

title: #tidytuesday Work Group
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! Work individually or with the group and end the evening by sharing your work.

We'll explore the Australia Fires data set available here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2020/2020-01-07 You can read more about the data set and associated online article via that link too.

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:15 pm Meet & Greet
6:15 - 7:30 pm #tidytuesday
7:30 - 8:00 pm Discussion

This is a great opportunity to meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build up your GitHub/Twitter/data science portfolio!

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together!

What should I bring?
Please bring your own laptop (fully-charged!) and all learning materials you want to use. If you have time, please look at the data set beforehand and think about some questions you'd like to answer with it.

Where will it take place?
Cocoa Cinnamon Lakewood

Will there be options to fuel up while I code?
Yes! Cocoa Cinnamon has all sorts of drinks (caffeinated and non-caffeinated) and delicious churros. On Tuesdays, the So Good Pupusas food truck will be parked outside of the coffee shop to serve up some El Salvadorian pupusas. More info here: https://www.sogoodpupusas.com/

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: **NEW DATE** R Markdown ‚Äì Composing Reproducible Documents with Graphs & Tables
description:
We are excited to invite you to our first event of 2020!
During this event, Martine Jansen will give a workshop on R Markdown. R Markdown provides a way to integrate code and report content into high quality documents. R Markdown documents are fully reproducible and support dozens of output formats. In this workshop we will create an R Markdown document, in which we use the tidyverse to read a csv and manipulate it. After adding some analyses and plots, we will write inline R code, so the text in the report changes depending on the data. We present the resulting analysis with one click in a nicely formatted Word document. After this workshop you will have the tools to start your own analysis projects with RStudio.

Martine Jansen works for Fontys University of Applied Sciences as an institutional researcher. Another form of this workshop was presented at the EAIR forum 2019 in Leiden and at R-Ladies Amsterdam.

**PLEASE NOTE THE CHANGED DATE**

Date: Tuesday, February 18th, 2020
Starting time: 6PM
Location: Avans Hogeschool Den Bosch (walking distance from train station)

As a local R-Ladies chapter, we want to host accessible workshops and create a community of R-enthusiasts where everyone can develop their R skills. Everyone who is interested in the R language and supports inclusion in the community is welcome to join.

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

Looking forward to meeting all of you!
-- Organizing team R-Ladies Den Bosch

title: Tidy Tuesday: Practicing Data Science in R
description:
Practice your data wrangling and visualization R skills with other members of R-Ladies! Tidy Tuesdays are designed by the R for Data Science Online Learning Community to help R users learn in a fun and real-world context.

Read more about Tidy Tuesdays here: https://www.tidytuesday.com/

Join us at the UF Biodiversity Institute during lunch to work on the Tidy Tuesday challenge as a group. Food will not be provided, but you are welcome to bring your own. Please bring your laptop. These events will supplement, not replace, our monthly meetings. Hope to see you there!

title: Reproducible research and how to do it with RMarkdown
description:
During this workshop, you will learn how to create reproducible research files with RMarkdown and how to share them.

We will go through the following subjects:
- Overview and structure of rmarkdown files
- Adding charts and tables to documents (PDF, HTML, etc.)
- Customize your document

Prerequisites if you want to code by yourself:
- R and RStudio installed on your machine
- Packages knitr, kable, tidyverse installed

If you want PDF documents with LaTeX you need to download:
- Windows user: MikTex (https://miktex.org/download)
- MacOS user: MacTex (https://www.tug.org/mactex/mactex-download.html)
- Linux user: Use package manager

If you want to get familiar with the subject beforehand, check this cheatsheet:
https://rstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/rmarkdown-cheatsheet.pdf

See you on Monday!

title: Tidy ThuRsday
description:
Join R-Ladies KC and practice your data cleaning and visualization skills in R on one of the Tidy Tuesday datasets (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday). The evening will include plenty of cross-collaboration and end with a discussion of our work.

Agenda:
6:30 - 6:45pm: Meet and Greet
6:45 - 7:45pm: ~Data Time~
7:45 - 8pm: Discussion

What is Tidy Tuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new dataset and accompanying README is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to create your own visualization and then share it on social media with #TidyTuesday for all to see!

description:

title: Intro to Shiny for interactive graphics and data visualization
description:
Join us on Feb. 11th as Emma Smith introduces us to Shiny.

Tired of presenting your research using the same old boring tables and figures? Shiny is a powerful R package that allows you to create interactive applications ranging from infographics and maps to business dashboards. This workshop will start by providing a walkthrough of the basic framework of Shiny applications, including the creation of interactive plots and tables. This will be followed by some tips on how to kick your apps up a notch using only one or two lines of code thanks to libraries such as shinyWidgets, shinydashboard, and plotly. Resources will be provided for those interested in creating more advanced dashboards or making their Shiny creations available online.

title: R Ladies Boulder Meetup #6: Bring Your Own Code Coding Hour
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's R Ladies Meetup: Bring Your Own Code Open Coding Hour!

This month we are hosting an open coding night at The Rayback Collective. This is a casual meetup for people to bring their projects, practice skills, and just mingle and share tips, tricks, and expeRtise. Use this time to work through R tutorials, a TidyTuesday challenge, or your own project.

We'll be there by 5:45pm and people are welcome to hang out until Rayback closes.

Can't wait to see you all there!

title: R-Ladies NOLA Launch Party!
description:
Greetings Everyone and Happy New Year!

There are no adequate words or strings of code for how excited we are to launch R-Ladies NOLA with a party fit for the roaring 20's that have just begun.

Whether you're an RStudio aficionado or merely data-curious, come celebrate the official kick-off of our new chapter and meet the techies you'll be bonding with over code in the months to come.

Wine, beer, coffee, tea and snacks will be omnipresent but feel free to bring treats of your own for solidarity. Got some friend with an itch for programming? Bring them along. The more the merrier it is as we take our first step in cultivating a community made of NOLA's finest data people.

Sincerely,
Your R-Ladies NOLA Co-Hosts, Danielle and Erin

title: R-Ladies Project Night
description:
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project focused on using tidyverse packages to clean, wrangle, tidy, and plot a new dataset every Tuesday.

We will be using a dataset from the TidyTuedsay Github (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday)
that has been tamed, but does not always adhere to ‚Äútidy‚Äù data principles. Our goal is to have you take a look at the raw data, and generate either a copy of the original plot or a novel take on the data! You can obviously use whatever techniques you feel are appropriate, but the data will be organized in a way that tidyverse tools will work well!

Schedule
6-6:30 -- Food and drinks, Intros & Announcements
6:30-7:30 -- R TidyTuesday Project Night
7:30-8:00-- Socializing/Networking/Hanging out/Chillin'

Q: Are men welcome to attend this event?
A: Our primary mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. ***As such, we strongly encourage that all men who attend this event have a female or non-binary sponsor. Please contact chicago@rladies.org if you have questions.***

Additionally, please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

‚Ä¢ What to bring
Yourself! And a laptop - this will be an interactive event.

‚Ä¢ Important to know
We expect all attendees to abide & be governed by our community code of conduct. Please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

‚Ä¢ Thank you to our sponsors!
We are grateful to 8th Light for hosting us this month and providing food!!

title: Introduction to R programming Language
description:
Dear all,

The goal of our first meetup is to become familiar with the basics of R programming language and learn how to use the R Studio environment in order to start your journey with R.

The workshop will cover:
*Description of RStudio environment
* Basic concepts of R language
* Basic data visualization in R

If there is still time we will talk about the Rmarkdown package and what R can offer you to produce your work in interactive way.

We recommend you bring your own laptop where you have
R and RStudio installed (https://cran.r-project.org/ and https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/).
In case you want to install Rmarkdown you can follow the instructions at https://bookdown.org/yihui/rmarkdown/installation.html

title: Comment sont g√©rer les donn√©es manquantes dans une r√©gression PLS ?
description: Les donn√©es manquantes sont pr√©sentes dans beaucoup de domaines de recherche. Plusieurs m√©thodes ont √©t√© d√©velopp√©es pour les traiter. La m√©thode d'imputation est le processus qui permet de g√©rer les donn√©es manquantes avant d'estimer les param√®tres d'un mod√®le. La r√©gression PLS est un mod√®le qui va permettre de les g√©rer. C'est une m√©thode qui est bas√©e sur deux algorithmes (SIMPLS ou NIPALS) qui peuvent √™tre utilis√©s pour fournir les estimations des param√®tres des mod√®les. La r√©gression PLS est tr√®s efficace pour analyser les relations de cause √† effet entre les variables r√©ponses et les composantes. L'algorithme NIPALS fournit des estimations sur de donn√©es incompl√®tes sans imputation. Notre objectif est √©tudier l‚Äôinfluence de la proportion de donn√©es manquantes sur l‚Äôestimation du nombre de composantes dans une r√©gression PLS pour une hypoth√®se MCAR.

title: 2020 Data Hack: Partner Presentations
description:
(for updates, go to the official hack page here: https://codeforphilly.org/events/datahack2020)

-------------- What is the hack? --------------

Code for Philly, DataPhilly, R Ladies Philly, the Philly Data Jawn, Health Federation of Philadelphia, and Prevention Point are hosting a data science hackathon to answer pertinent questions around the Opioid Crisis in Philadelphia. The goals of this event are to provide health organizations with insights that may normally be unavailable to them and to create analyses that help inform the public about the opioid epidemic in our city.

Hackathon planners have been working with our partners to identify and clean relevant datasets that would be helpful in answering these broader questions:

1) Can we visualize current capacity for Medication Assisted Interventions in Philadelphia to streamline referrals?
2) What have been the effects of granting citizens access to Narcan?
3) How many IV drug users are in Philadelphia?

-------------- How will it work? --------------

The hack is slated to begin on Friday February 7, 2020 with a kickoff event. Partner organizations will present what their group does and why these questions are relevant to them. The next day, participants will have several hours to form their team, consider the questions, and devise a plan to conduct their relevant analysis. Over the next five weeks, these teams will work on their analyses and write their presentations.

-------------- Event Breakdown --------------

Feb 7, 2020 (Friday): Partner presentation night
Feb 8, 2020 (Saturday): First hack day
Feb 11, 2020 (Tuesday): Code for Philly Hack Night
Feb 18, 2020 (Tuesday): Code for Philly Hack Night
Feb 25, 2020 (Tuesday): Code for Philly Hack Night
March 3, 2020 (Tuesday): Code for Philly Hack Night
March 10, 2020 (Tuesday): Code for Philly Hack Night
March 17, 2020 (Tuesday): Presentation night

Participants are not required to attend all events - hack nights are there for teams to have a space and time to regroup. Some hack nights will also have valuable workshops designed to help teams with their analysis and final presentations. In order to give each team a sufficient amount of time on presentation night, there will be no more than 12 teams. Each team is allowed to have as many members as they want.

-------------- How do I sign up? --------------

Given that this is a multi-group effort, we want to avoid possible confusion about which platform to register on. We therefore are keeping Meetup.com registration closed, and ask all participants to register via this Eventbrite link: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/2020-data-hack-data-science-for-a-healthier-community-tickets-86813763303

title: Data streaming with Apache Flink
description:
Ververica is the new name of data Artisans, the company founded in 2014 by the original creators of Apache Flink¬Æ. with headquartered in Berlin, Germany.

They started Data Artisans (now Ververica) because they saw the need for a large-scale data processing technology that is open source and at the same time properly rooted in long-tested principles and architectures from the database and distributed systems fields.

From the very beginning, they developed Apache Flink¬Æ in the open source, and they witnessed and led Flink‚Äôs rapid community growth and industry adoption.

The meetup will be about Stateful Stream Processing
The volume of data generated in the world continues to grow steadily. The ability to process these in real time not only opens up new applications but often becomes a necessity to maintain a competitive edge. We will discuss how the horizontally scalable Stateful Stream Processing responds to these new demands and why it can be considered an evolution of the Batch Processing approach. We will also look at the technical complexities involved in building such distributed systems and how they have been resolved in Apache Flink.

Speaker: Alexander Fedulov, Solutions Architect at Ververica

Alexander Fedulov is a Solutions Architect at Ververica (formerly data Artisans). He is advising customers with application design, system integration and performance tuning. Prior to joining Ververica, Alexander worked as a developer and consultant in a variety of companies based in Berlin. He has a Masters Degree (M.Sc.) from the Technical University of Hamburg (TUHH).

Event is totally free to attend, but RSVP is required.
Food and drinks for networking part will be provided:

More information and registration is here:
https://apacheflink.splashthat.com

Follow announcements at FB event: www.facebook.com/events/1009261019432222

title: Survey analysis: beyond the subscripts
description:
Abstract:
Analysing complex sampling -- cluster samples, unequal probabilities, stratification -- used to be a separate and somewhat isolated area of statistics. Some books on the topic might have given the impression it was mostly about the care and feeding of subscripts. In fact, well-conducted complex sampling gives data with important differences from other data sources, but ones whose impact on the analysis is limited. Modern survey analysis software is aimed at reducing the differences to a minimum, so analysts and domain experts can analyse complex surveys correctly in most straightforward cases. I will talk about how you can use the R survey package to do most of the analyses you already do, but with data from complex surveys. ‚Äã

Bio:
Thomas Lumley is originally from Australia, but worked in Seattle, at the University of Washington, for 12 years. He is currently Professor of Biostatistics at the University of Auckland, where he teaches statistics and data science. Thomas is the developer of the R survey package, and a member of R Core. He has taught workshops on R in 13 time zones.

title: Intro to Tidyverse
description:
We will give an overview of the tidyverse-way of data handling giving you hands-on examples on how to read in, manipulate, and plot data. @Jonelle will be giving us special fresh tips, as she will be attending Hadley Wickham's tutorial at the rstudio:conf 2020 a few days before the meeting!

To get a quick overview of Hadley's way of thinking, read: https://joss.theoj.org/papers/10.21105/joss.01686

Please bring your laptop with RStudio (https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/) and Tidyverse (https://www.tidyverse.org/) installed. We will provide coffee, tea, and some snacks.

title: R Markdown and tips from the RStudio Conference
description:
For our first meeting of 2020 we have two talks lined up:

Rebecca Killick (Lancaster University): R Markdown and why I love it (workshop)

R Markdown is a fantastic tool allowing users to write a huge variety of documents with R code embedded. Rebecca will introduce R Markdown and explain why she loves using it. She'll also teach us how to create a simple R Markdown document. If you want to to participate in the interactive element, please bring a laptop with RStudio and R installed. If you have chance also install the knitr package by running the following command.

install.packages("knitr")

---

Rhian Davies (Jumping Rivers) : What I learnt at RStudio Conference

I'm lucky to be attending the RStudio Conference this year. I'll give a talk summarising some of the new and exciting things I learnt at the conference to share with you all!

---
We will be in Lancaster University Library - Room C135. The session will run from 6pm - 8pm with a short break in the middle. Snacks and soft drinks will be provided.

---

R-Ladies Lancaster is part of a global initiative, R-Ladies Global, designed to improve the gender diversity of R users worldwide and in particular, to improve the participation and experience of women in the R community. As part of the initiative, R-Ladies Lancaster will host a number of talks and workshops about the use of R. It doesn't matter if you never used R or if you are an R expert, R-Ladies Lancaster welcomes anyone with an interest in R.

Questions? E-mail: lancaster@rladies.org

description: Join us for some socializing! Whether you have come to a dozen or zero meetups so far, we'd love to get to know you. We'll have our own space (the barrel room in back). There's no fee to attend, but you are in charge of paying for whatever you consume. Urban Growler has great beer, food, and sodas.

title: Tidy Tuesday - Come and practice your R skills
description:
Do you want to practice your R-skills? Do you want to improve your abilities to clean, analyse and plot data?

Then this event is what you need! We will use the data from Tidy Tuesday as an excuse to work with R. We will meet to work independently using the same data-set. Each one can choose which analysis to perform or which tools to use (you can already think what you want to practice or learn). We will do this together to have the opportunity to ask others and because coding together is fun!

This activity is for everyone, from beginners to experts. You will set your own goal. We will have a coffee (or what ever you prefer) while working together. This way we can have the opportunity to ask others, to share ideas and code!!

Tidy Tuesday a weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem. Every week a new data set is uploaded and analysed by the community, then the plots can be shared! Las week data from the fires in Australia was analysed. Have a look at some of the community plots on Tweeter:

https://twitter.com/hashtag/tidytuesday

Bring your own laptop. Hopefully with enough battery.

title: R-Ladies Manchester Fun with Functions!
description:
R-Ladies first event of 2020

The wonderful Autotrader have agreed to have us back for our first event of 2020 and Kaylea is going to be teaching us all how to "do" functions after giving several impromptu lessons at previous meet-ups!

There will be an "intro to functions" talk to ease you in, with a short hands on session to try it out.

Then we'll kick things up a notch and do some more advanced function uses; think the apply family, pipes and map, again breaking off into groups to try it out.

Then finally we'll open the floor up to your questions and make sure everybody leaves with at least one function that works!

This slightly more intermediate level lesson is still perfect for you if you are new to coding - the sooner you start using functions the sooner you can master them - don't be intimidated - bring your laptop along and we'll help you hit the ground running!

Auto Trader, our venue hosts strive to ensure all events are inclusive, accessible and that all those attending feel as comfortable as possible.
Therefore, whilst signing up, please tell us if you have any of the following requirements:
- Dietary
- Allergies
- Accessibility or specific requirements

title: R-Ladies Jakarta 6th Meetup: introduction to R Shiny.
description:
Happy new year, R enthusiasts!!! We're having out sixth meetup, real soon!

Sunday, 2nd February 2020 from 14.00-17.00 WIB, at Mozilla Community Space Jakarta, Jl. Kuningan Bar. 1 No.26, Mampang Prapatan, DKI Jakarta 12710

We will have a refreshing topic as we commence our yearlong R-Ladies series of meet-ups, and what better way to start through learning Shiny apps in R with our always awesome Erika Siregar? So, hurry and join us!

"Shiny is an R package that makes it easy to build interactive web apps straight from R. You can host standalone apps on a webpage or embed them in R Markdown documents or build dashboards. "

Some IMPORTANT stuff:
1. Our current space can have maximum 25 persons, so hurry up reserve your spot!
2. Check previous meetups docs here: https://github.com/RLadiesJakarta
3. E-mail us at jakarta@rladies.org or tweet to "@rladiesjakarta" for any inquiries regarding this event!
4. Don't forget to have RStudio readily installed in your computer
5. If you're very new to R, you can also go through these two documents before the meetup:
1. Intro to R.pdf
2. Starter Kit R.pdf
You can download and read the descriptions here: https://github.com/RLadiesJakarta/starter-kit

title: Code and Coffee: A collaboration with PyData Pune
description:
R-Ladies Pune collaborates with PyData Pune to host a Code and Coffee event!

Ready to show your R skills ladies ?

The concept is simple, bring a laptop and code. Here's how it works:

1. At 09:45 am, everyone introduces themselves.
2. At 10:00 am, We will share and discuss the problem statements and necessary stuff.
3. For the rest of the day, folks work in the communal space on their code providing one another help and conversation as needed. Oh, and they usually drink coffee too!.
---------------------------------------------
What to bring??
-- Laptop with charged batteries
-- Adaptor and cord

Others
-- Install RStudio
----------------------------

title: R-Ladies Calgary inaugural meetup
description:
Welcome to R-Ladies Calgary!

This is our first meeting and we would love to meet as many of you as possible! Come along and meet fellow R enthusiasts, have some snacks, and help us decide the direction for the Calgary Chapter.

For those of you who aren't sure what R-Ladies is about, it is a worldwide organisation that aims to achieve proportionate representation of minority genders in the R community (including but not limited to cis/trans women, trans men, non-binary, genderqueer, agender).

Please fill out the following questionnaire before attending: https://forms.gle/g9w6BZQ83V28BQ8a8

Room: 0-13 Meeting Room at the Central Library

We are looking forward to meeting you!

title: Arkansas Center for Data Science Recruiter to Provide Webinar
description:
I‚Äôm so excited to announce that on Friday the 31st at 3PM, Katie Frazier, a recruiter for the Arkansas Center for Data Science (ACDS) will provide a **FREE** webinar to talk about the mission of ACDS.

She will discuss the following topics:

ACDS purpose
What is an apprenticeship?
Apprenticeships in Arkansas
What do we look for?
What is our interview process?
What companies do we work with?
Tips for applications/resumes

Please join this webinar by link : https://zoom.us/j/2089095106?pwd=Nk95MW9JeklBMjdLa3VMNE5lcjAwZz09

We hope to see many familiar names and hear some amazing questions for Katie! Please share this widely and freely if you know someone who might be interested in the opportunities that ACDS has.

title: rstudio::conf 2020 Keynote Watch Party
description:
The RStudio conference (rstudio::conf) is in San Francisco this year but you can join R-Ladies RTP, Duke University Department of Statistics, and Duke University Libraries as we livestream the conference from Durham, NC. We'll watch the closing keynote talk presented by Roger Peng (John Hopkins University) and Hilary Parker (Stitch Fix) who host the Not So Standard Deviations podcast. This keynote will be their 100th episode! According to the rstudio::conf agenda, Hilary and Roger will discuss "...creativity, its role in data science, and how it can be fostered through conversation. Also, follow up on coffee and oat milk." You can find info about their podcast and give it a listen at: http://nssdeviations.com/ .

**RSVP is required but is not through Meetup.com.** To sign up for this event, please register via the Duke University event website here (https://duke.libcal.com/event/6321006). The event is open to the public; you do not have to be a student/faculty/staff of Duke.

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike!

When is this?
Jan, 30 from 7-8pm (Feel free to come as early as 6:30pm to chat with other R-Ladies RTP members.)

Where is this?
Duke University, Bostock Library, Room 127

Where do I park?
We recommend you park at the Bryan Center Parking Lot/Garage. Parking is $2/hour.

title: Podaci o zagaƒëenju vazduha: Kako ih prikupljamo, a kako vizualizujemo?
description:
Prvi R Ladies meetup ove godine odr≈æaƒáe se na temu podataka o zagaƒëenju vazduha. Kao i svake prethodne zime, Beograd je i sada na listi najzagaƒëenijih gradova.

Prvi deo meetupa ƒáe se fokusirati na vizualizaciju podataka o zagaƒëanju vazduha u R-u, prezentaciju ƒáe odr≈æati Jovana Saviƒá i Katarina Kosmina. Fokus drugog dela meetupa biƒáe diskusija o graƒëanskom merenju kvaliteta vazduha ‚Äì kako mo≈æemo da unapredimo trenutno prikupljanje i prikazivanje podataka? Diskusija se odr≈æava u okviru inicijative ‚ÄûVidljivi podaci za nevidljivi vazduh‚Äú, koji sprovodi Beogradska otvorena ≈°kola u saradnji sa Internet dru≈°tvom Srbije i IoT kompanijom AllThingsTalk.

description:

title: Using R and RStudio with Amazon Web Services (with Katie Heineman)
description:
The goal of the tutorial will be to install Rstudio Server and Shiny Server on an EC2 Amazon Web Services cloud computing instance.

Before the meeting - I encourage you to sign up for the free tier of Amazon Web Services! You will be required to enter a credit card number, but the plan itself is free.
https://aws.amazon.com/free/?all-free-tier.sort-by=item.additionalFields.SortRank&all-free-tier.sort-order=asc

The tutorial was written for a Linux/Mac operating system - PC users may want to download PuTTY to emulate the terminal interface that we will be using. https://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/latest.html

title: BYOD (bring your own data) and get started with R
description:
Is learning R on your New Years resolution list? This is the event for you!!

In this workshop, we are going to start at the very beginning, teaching you how to get YOUR data into R and how to clean it up a bit. This workshop is designed for ABSOLUTE BEGINNERS.

You will need to bring...
1. a laptop
2. a .csv data file
3. enthusiasm and perseverance

So that we have some data to work with initially, please help us out by completing this Sound of Music themed survey.

https://forms.gle/4fRvs9jQvmKsen4f7

title: January Event: Data Gets Personal
description:
In this talk, Louisa Smith will describe her experience collecting and analyzing some very personal data: data relating to her breast cancer treatment. From digging deep into her health insurance website to tracking her drug-induced hot flashes, Louisa will detail how she ended up with the data in this powerful twitter thread: https://twitter.com/louisahsmith/status/1179429494664388609. Whether you are interested in learning more about collecting data about yourself or just want to know how R can serve both as a tool to cope during stressful times and as a tool for advocacy, join us!

Louisa is currently a PhD candidate in epidemiology at Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health. She has been using R for five years in both her professional and personal lives. You can find her at https://www.louisahsmith.com and on twitter @louisahsmith.

Pizza will be served (thanks to BMS!) and the presentation will begin at 6:15

title: R-Ladies Baltimore -- Shiny apps!
description:
R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is the local Baltimore chapter for the larger R-Ladies global organization (rladies.org) to promote gender diversity in the R community.

We will have an event on Wednesday January 29, 2020 from 5:30-7pm at Allovue (https://allovue.com). Amanda Plunkett (https://twitter.com/DrAmandaRP) will present on what are Shiny apps, how you can you can build them, and demo-ing a few ones we love! Come learn how to make interactive web apps with R shiny! This will be a hands-on presentation, so bring your laptop.

Also, come prepared with:
- RStudio installed
- R packages installed: shiny, shinydashboard, shinythemes, tidyverse, gghighlight, lubridate, latex2exp, sf, mapview

WHO is this for?
- If you are new to R & are short-budgeted on time!
- If you heard of this thing called 'Shiny' in R, but no idea what it is!
- If you know about Shiny apps, but no idea how to build one!
- If you just want to see some awesome examples of web applications in R!

*If any/all of this is true, this event might be for you!*

AGENDA
5:30‚Äì5:45 Meet & Greet | üç™ | Networking
5:45‚Äì5:50 Who we are | Announcements | What's next
5:50‚Äì6:30 Presentation: What are Shiny Apps and how can you build one?
6:30-6:45 Discussion with audience on other questions / resources
6:45‚Äì7:00 More üç™ and Networking

Details on the location:
Allovue (https://allovue.com)
301 W 29th St, Baltimore, MD 21211
(Room 2003, on the second floor at the end of the hall)

Details on parking: Parking is available at R House (https://r.housebaltimore.com) as well as across the street at the police station or in Remington Row‚Äôs Garage (entrance on 28th Street, that is paid parking though).
FAQ:
Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. However, we ask that cis men come as guests of women and gender minorities to our events to promote a sense support and encouragement for women and gender minorities in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies. Please also take the time to review our code of conduct before you attend: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

The term "women and gender minorities" is inclusive of individuals who identify as female (trans and cis), trans-men, non-binary, genderqueer, genderfluid, agender, intersex, and all minority genders).

Important to know:
- If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

Finally, for more information:

twitter: @RLadiesBmore
website: https://rladies-baltimore.github.io
facebook: https://www.facebook.com/RLadiesBmore/
meetup: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-baltimore/

title: rstudio::conf(2020) Watch Party
description:
Rstudio::conf(2020) watch party in cooperation with RStudio, RLadiesBerlin, BerlinR, and the Berlin RUG!

Let us enjoy the conference without having to trek to San Francisco. We'll watch and discuss live streams together, enjoy RStudio trinkets and have food and drinks as well.

Schedule
***********************************
5 pm - Just before the first keynote, a live-streamed pre-game event will feature short interviews with folks from RStudio as well as the wider R-Community. During this event, we will have an opportunity to interact with the host and guests in real time.

6pm - The pre-game event will lead directly into the keynote and session live-streams. We aim to watch the first two keynote talks of the conference together and we can pose questions to the speakers.

Keynotes:
- Open Source Software for Data Science, J.J. Allaire - Hosts, Founder and CEO RStudio
- Data, visualization, and designing with AI, Fernanda Viegas and Martin Wattenberg, Google

9pm - We draw the winners from a little raffle game we prepared :)

About rstudio::conf:
***********************************
Featuring two days of content with more than 70 sessions and lightning talks, rstudio::conf will welcome more than 2000 attendees to listen, discuss, and explore what‚Äôs possible with R and RStudio.

Link to Agenda: https://tinyurl.com/yyvyx66c

********************************************************************************
stay tuned for more details!

description:

The host is Hadley Wickham, Chief Scientist of RStudio, and the keynote speakers are Hilary Parker (Stitch Fix), Roger Peng (Johns Hopkins), Martin Wattenberg, Fernanda Viegas (Research Scientists, Google), Jenny Bryan (Engineer, RStudio) and JJ Allaire (CEO, RStudio).

We got invited to join this exciting event together via the so called watch parties where we watch first the pre-game event just before the first keynote. "This live-streamed pre-game event will feature short interviews with folks from RStudio as well as the wider R-Community. During this event the attendees at the watch parties will have an opportunity to interact with the host and guests in real time. The pre-game event will lead directly into the keynote and session live-streams."

title: #ShutUpandCode
description:
Learning something new on your own is hard! So lets meet up and learn new R things together.

This month we are getting together at UTS to meet up, shut up (talking is allowed if you are seeking/getting help), and code.

Modelled on the academic writing #ShutUpAndWrite movement (https://thesiswhisperer.com/shut-up-and-write/), the idea is make learning social.

There are only 10 places available at each session, so ONLY RSVP if you are SURE you will come. Please do not take a place from another RLady, and then not turn up.

This live-streamed pre-game event will feature short interviews with folks from RStudio as well as the wider R-Community. During this event, the attendees at the watch parties will have an opportunity to interact with the host and guests in real-time. The pre-game event will lead directly into the keynote and session live-streams.

During this meetup we'll watch the keynote from J.J. Allaire (RStudio) and Fernanda Viegas and Martin Wattenberg (Google Brain). Watch party attendees will be able to submit questions to the keynoters and we'll have some RStudio swag to give away!

Feel free to join us for as long as you want. You don't need to be the whole three hours to attend.

title: Tidy Tuesday - Come and practice your R skills
description:
Do you want to practice your R-skills? Do you want to improve your abilities to clean, analyse and plot data?

Then this event is what you need! We will use the data from Tidy Tuesday as an excuse to work with R. We will meet to work independently using the same data-set. Each one can choose which analysis to perform or which tools to use (you can already think what you want to practice or learn). We will do this together to have the opportunity to ask others and because coding together is fun!

This activity is for everyone, from beginners to experts. You will set your own goal. We will have a coffee (or what ever you prefer) while working together. This way we can have the opportunity to ask others, to share ideas and code!!

Tidy Tuesday a weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem. Every week a new data set is uploaded and analysed by the community, then the plots can be shared! Las week data from the fires in Australia was analysed. Have a look at some of the community plots on Tweeter:

https://twitter.com/hashtag/tidytuesday

Bring your own laptop. Hopefully with enough battery.

title: Meetup Janeiro 2020 - Vamos aprender usar Shinydashboard
description:

title: R + Tableau: Let‚Äôs Enrich Data Science with More Visualizations
description:
Hong Wang, data scientist at Independent Purchasing Cooperative, which is a supply chain management company and provides supply chain service for Subway (US top 2 quick service restaurant brand). The general business is to assure that all Subway restaurants both in US and Canada operate successfully with high quality products and most competitive cost. As a data scientist at IPC, Hong provides in-depth analytical insights and systematic applications, which are both important to improve business. She applies mathematical approaches to solve business questions and enable business stakeholders to make decisions based on my analysis or recommendations.

At IPC, Tableau is used as a reporting application that is able to connect directly to R. The functionality is designed for the domain expert who understands the data and is able to make data science results more visual to broaden audience. The drag-and-drop interface allows users effortlessly connect to libraries and packages, import saved models or write new ones directly into calculations and visualize them in seconds.

Hello RiveRside community ;-)

Come join us for another afternoon of networking and sharing (and pizza!), on Thursday, January 23rd at 4:30pm, at Rivera Library 140. Whether you are new to R or a data scientist, come talk about the wonders of using R Markdown (and please don't forget to register).

As per usual, we will start by learning from two of our fellow R enthusiasts and their 5-min lightning talks. Email us if you are interested in being one of them (riverside@rladies.org). We will then work through a hands-on tutorial on the basics of R Markdown so you can start writing papers and making presentations in R, among (a lot of!) other things. Once again, please bring your laptop with R and RStudio already installed.

Big thanks to UCR Library and UCR GradQuant for supporting us!

See you soon,

Teresa, Marilia & Daniela

title: Sanofi and Data Science: Forecasting, what and how
description:
In this talk we will explore what it‚Äôs like to be a Statistical Forecaster at Sanofi and how to apply statistical and machine learning methods to timeseries data.

19:00 - 20:30: ‚ÄúSanofi and Data Science: Forecasting, what and how‚Äù workshop by Alexandra Ab√≥s
20:30 - 21:00: Pica-pica & Networking

**WARNING** The registration for this event is done through eventbrite. Please register at the following link or you will not be granted a space: https://www.eventbrite.es/e/entradas-sanofi-and-data-science-forecasting-what-and-how-88399524357

--> About Time Series Forecasting
Time Series forecasting is a hot topic in the pharma industry. However, what do we understand as time series? What are the most recent trends in the market and requirements to analyze this data? How does a top tier pharmaceutical company use time series for sales forecasting?

If you‚Äôre eager to know the answer to these questions, please join our next meet-up event!

**WARNING** The registration for this event is done through eventbrite. Please register at the following link or you will not be granted a space: https://www.eventbrite.es/e/entradas-sanofi-and-data-science-forecasting-what-and-how-88399524357

--> About Alexandra Abos
Alexandra graduated in Biomedical Engineering at UB in 2015 and has a PhD in machine learning and graph theory applied to medical imaging. She is currently working as Statistical Forecaster at the pharmaceutical company Sanofi where she focuses on time series forecasting.

--> Where?
Sanofi Offices (Meridian Building, Carrer de Rossell√≥ i Porcel, 21, 08016 Barcelona)

--> What do you need to follow this workshop?
This is a talk, not a workshop so you don't need to bring anything more than your curiosity!

--> Attending the Meetup
Remember that in the R-Ladies Meetups we expect to have a majority of R-Ladies, so if you are a man you should come with another R-Lady or invite a non-male friend to the Meetup!

**WARNING** The registration for this event is done through eventbrite. Please register at the following link or you will not be granted a space: https://www.eventbrite.es/e/entradas-sanofi-and-data-science-forecasting-what-and-how-88399524357

title: Tidy Tuesday - Come and practice your R skills
description:
Do you want to practice your R-skills? Do you want to improve your abilities to clean, analyse and plot data?

Then this event is what you need! We will use the data from Tidy Tuesday as an excuse to work with R. We will meet to work independently using the same data-set. Each one can choose which analysis to perform or which tools to use (you can already think what you want to practice or learn). We will do this together to have the opportunity to ask others and because coding together is fun!

This activity is for everyone, from beginners to experts. You will set your own goal. We will have a coffee (or what ever you prefer) while working together. This way we can have the opportunity to ask others, to share ideas and code!!

Tidy Tuesday a weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem. Every week a new data set is uploaded and analysed by the community, then the plots can be shared! Las week data from the fires in Australia was analysed. Have a look at some of the community plots on Tweeter:

https://twitter.com/hashtag/tidytuesday

Bring your own laptop.

title: Books In Bars - How to Lie with Maps
description:
Spend Friday night discussing How to Lie with Maps (https://www.amazon.com/How-Lie-Maps-Mark-Monmonier/dp/0226534219).

Originally published to wide acclaim, this lively, cleverly illustrated essay on the use and abuse of maps teaches us how to evaluate maps critically and promotes a healthy skepticism about these easy-to-manipulate models of reality. Monmonier shows that, despite their immense value, maps lie. In fact, they must.

The second edition is updated with the addition of two new chapters, 10 color plates, and a new foreword by renowned geographer H. J. de Blij. One new chapter examines the role of national interest and cultural values in national mapping organizations, including the United States Geological Survey, while the other explores the new breed of multimedia, computer-based maps.

To show how maps distort, Monmonier introduces basic principles of mapmaking, gives entertaining examples of the misuse of maps in situations from zoning disputes to census reports, and covers all the typical kinds of distortions from deliberate oversimplifications to the misleading use of color.

"Professor Monmonier himself knows how to gain our attention; it is not in fact the lies in maps but their truth, if always approximate and incomplete, that he wants us to admire and use, even to draw for ourselves on the facile screen. His is an artful and funny book, which like any good map, packs plenty in little space."‚ÄîScientific American

"A useful guide to a subject most people probably take too much for granted. It shows how map makers translate abstract data into eye-catching cartograms, as they are called. It combats cartographic illiteracy. It fights cartophobia. It may even teach you to find your way. For that alone, it seems worthwhile."‚ÄîChristopher Lehmann-Haupt, The New York Times

". . . witty examination of how and why maps lie. [The book] conveys an important message about how statistics of any kind can be manipulated. But it also communicates much of the challenge, aesthetic appeal, and sheer fun of maps. Even those who hated geography in grammar school might well find a new enthusiasm for the subject after reading Monmonier's lively and surprising book."‚ÄîWilson Library Bulletin

"A reading of this book will leave you much better defended against cheap atlases, shoddy journalism, unscrupulous advertisers, predatory special-interest groups, and others who may use or abuse maps at your expense."‚ÄîJohn Van Pelt, Christian Science Monitor

"Monmonier meets his goal admirably. . . . [His] book should be put on every map user's 'must read' list. It is informative and readable . . . a big step forward in helping us to understand how maps can mislead their readers."‚ÄîJeffrey S. Murray, Canadian Geographic

PS Please contact the organizer if you need support finding the book.

title: Resolutions 2020!
description:
For our January meetup we'll go over what we have achieved in the last year and where we are hoping to go in 2020. After the presentation, we will have some time to network and chat about all the exciting things to come.

Whether you have attended one of our previous meetups or not, anyone who supports our mission and has an interest in R is welcome. You can be an R expert or complete beginner!

In the first part of this meetup, we will (re-)introduce you to R-Ladies Philadelphia, which is celebrating a successful 2019. We will recap our programming and initiatives, how we have grown, and what we have learned. Looking ahead, we will discuss our plans for 2020 and how you can get involved. We would love to receive your input on what you‚Äôd like to see from R-Ladies Philly in the new year. Our annual member survey can be accessed from http://bit.ly/2019rladies. We would like to hear from you! It only takes 1~2 minutes.

The second part of the meetup will be geared towards networking with other attendees. The theme will be R-related new year‚Äôs resolutions. We will facilitate this networking session to help you meet attendees with similar resolutions or an expert who can recommend resources or strategies that can help you achieve your goals.

-----
**Getting there**

- The Roberts Center room 120A-B (2716 South Street) is walking distance from the University City Regional Rail Station, and 40, 7, and 12 Septa bus lines.
- Outdoor bike parking is available along Schuylkill Avenue.
- Paid guest parking ($16 flat fee) is available in the Roberts Center‚Äôs surface parking lot which is accessible via Schuylkill Avenue. Parking tickets are dispensed at the point of entry and must be validated at the front desk in the 1st floor lobby. Payment for parking tickets must be made at the parking kiosk located on level B of the Roberts Center.
- Please reach out with any questions about accessibility and/or accommodations for the event.

-----
**Event Sponsor**

Location space and refreshments are generously provided by the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia's iSTEM Employee Resource Group: "iSTEM engages employees and serves our patient population by addressing disparities in the biomedical science, technology, engineering, and math workforce. We seek to promote breakthroughs in child health by improving the cultural competency of the STEM professional community at CHOP and providing educational and employment opportunities to under-represented youth in CHOP's catchment area. Our four-part mission is to develop programs that support our STEM workforce, their workplace, create STEM education opportunities for our patient community, and sustain our work through volunteerism and external grant funding.‚Äù

title: Visualization of Gene Expression Data & How to Successfully Start a New Job
description:
# Schedule
Tuesday, January 14th, 6:30-8:30pm
6:30 - [Networking Activity] R-Ladies Networking Bingo
7:00 - Announcements
7:05 - [Career Corner] How to Successfully Start a New Job
7:20 - 10-Minute Break
7:30 - [R Time] Visualization of Gene Expression Data
8:00 - Socializing and Networking
8:30 - Meeting Adjourned

# Meeting Location
UC Irvine Campus
School of Medicine
Gillespie Neuroscience Research Facility
Floor 1 Conference Room
Here are a few helpful maps of UCI to help you find us: https://www.parking.uci.edu/maps/map_services.cfm

# Parking
- All vehicles parked on the UC Irvine campus are required to display a valid parking permit at all times. Permit dispensers are available in all parking structures/lots at all times and accept major credit cards (Visa, MasterCard, American Express, Discover) and cash. If you don't already have a parking permit, parking is $2/hr. The closest parking lots to the event are lots 82, 83, and 84.
- Here are a few helpful maps of UCI to help you find where to park: https://www.parking.uci.edu/maps/map_services.cfm

# Food & Freebies
- Healthy vegan and gluten-free snacks and water will be provided.
- Free R-Ladies and tidyverse stickers will also be given out.

# Presentations
[Career Corner] How to Successfully Start a New Job
Speaker: Alyssa Columbus

[R Time] Visualization of Gene Expression Data
Speaker: Stacey Borrego, PhD
Abstract:
As a biologist, data visualization is an essential tool to aide in the understanding of the meaning of experimental results. While the common heatmap allows us to gain a global view of count data such as gene expression or metabolomic data, it can also be helpful to isolate select observations for visualization in individual plots. This talk will demonstrate automated plotting of gene expression data for each gene in a cellular pathway using a time course dataset. The data visualization package ggplot2 will be used and the function tryCatch() will be implemented to handle possible errors.

- ***NEW*** All announcements and presentations will be livestreamed and recorded starting at 7:00 PM. Join us at this link: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIbS1KNK7jbcbQVNt7lF62A/live
- All materials will be sent out and posted on our GitHub (https://github.com/rladies-irvine) and website (https://www.rladiesirvine.org/) after the event.

title: #tidytuesday Work Group
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! Work individually or with the group and end the evening by sharing your work.

We'll explore the PetFinder data set available here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2019/2019-12-17 . You can read more about the data set and associated online article via that link too.

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:15 pm Meet & Greet
6:15 - 7:30 pm #tidytuesday
7:30 - 8:00 pm Discussion

This is a great opportunity to meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build up your GitHub/Twitter/data science portfolio!

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together!

What should I bring?
Please bring your own laptop (fully-charged!) and all learning materials you want to use. If you have time, please look at the data set beforehand and think about some questions you'd like to answer with it.

Where will it take place?
Cocoa Cinnamon Lakewood

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: RMarkdown and Bookdown for Dissertating
description:
This month's meet up, Thea Knowles will return to lead us through an interactive tutorial on preparing to write a dissertation using RMarkdown and Bookdown. This month also marks 3 awesome years of R-Ladies London!

RMarkdown allows you to seamlessly integrate R code and narrative text as well as specify formatting options across multiple document output types (docx, pdf, html). Bookdown serves as a means to combining multiple RMarkdown files into a final book*.

This workshop will feature a crash course on RMarkdown and will cover the following: reference management in RMarkdown, tips for a modular workflow, integrating templates (like Western's thesis templates) into RMarkdown/bookdown documents, and more.

*"Despite the package name containing the word ‚Äúbook‚Äù, bookdown is not only for books. The ‚Äúbook‚Äù can be anything that consists of multiple R Markdown documents meant to be read in a linear sequence, such as course handouts, study notes, a software manual, a thesis, or even a diary." - Yihui Xie https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/

We'll kick off the year with a hands-on working session where we'll work together on our own projects or tutorials.

Come in curious about a subject or looking to make progress on a project you're working on!

We'll divide ourselves into groups who'll be working on similar topics, and we'll have prompts and tutorials at hand for those who don't have a particular project in mind.

We believe that by collaborating with other R-Ladies who share your curiosity you‚Äôll get much further than you would at home with google, and that even if you don‚Äôt have a set goal you‚Äôll learn through sharing and receiving tips and tricks.

All experience levels welcome!

We'll have five groups, for those working on projects related to:
1 - Making your website with R and blogdown
2 - Building a package
3 - Tidy Tuesday
4 - Forecasting with time series data
5 - Everything else!

Thank you to AT&T for hosting us and the R Conference and Lander Analytics for sponsoring pizza.

venues.name: AT&T NYC Data Science Research Center

title: R configuration and purrr
description:
Kara Woo will present a workshop on R configuration, maintaining R, and how to repeat yourself with purrr. The workshop will cover the 5th and 8th modules of the two-day What They Forgot to Teach You About R workshop (https://rstudio-conf-2020.github.io/what-they-forgot/).

This workshop is designed for experienced R and RStudio users who want to (re)design their R lifestyle. You should take this workshop if you‚Äôve been using R for a while, you feel like writing R code is not what‚Äôs holding you back the most, and you want to learn more about your R installation.

This is a hands-on workshop, so please bring a laptop with a current version of R and RStudio installed. RSVPing helps us know how many people to expect, but is not required.

This event is NOT sponsored by The Seattle Public Library.

venues.name: University Branch - The Seattle Public Library

title: Introduction to R Language
description: In Introduction to R, you will master the basics of this widely used open source language, including factors, lists, and data frames. With the knowledge gained in this workshop, you will be ready to undertake your first very own data analysis and begin your journey with R.

title: Tidyverse Skills: GGplot I - Data Visualization
description: Please remember to park in the lot across Palm. Thanks!

title: Analysing Twitter Data
description: In this meetup we will learn the basics of accessing, cleaning, wrangling and visualizing Twitter data. If you'd like, you can install the following packages beforehand - "tidyverse", "tm", "rtweet", "wordcloud2" and "tidytext".
